Our results of operations in the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021 were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Following the outbreak of the pandemic in March 2020, we promptly undertook all actions necessary to minimize the social and occupational health and safety and financial impacts of the pandemic by defining and implementing flexible and timely action plans. Among other things, we invested in personal protective equipment and implemented a series of social distancing, cleaning and other health and safety measures to ensure the safety of the employees at our production facilities. At the same time, we successfully transitioned a portion of our corporate employees to remote working over a short period of time. To manage our cost structure, reduce our use of cash and further preserve our liquidity position during the pandemic, we implemented several COVID-19 crisis management initiatives including, among others, the reduction of temporary workers and other short-term cost reduction measures such as the reduction of marketing and travel expenses, which limited 15 ----- the negative impact on our profit margins. At the same time, we focused on reducing our personnel expense, including by placing certain employees on temporary furlough schemes, and took advantage of government support programs, including salary subsidies, in the United Kingdom and in countries across Europe, such as Italy and Spain. We also benefited from certain changes in tax rules introduced as a result of COVID-19 in most of our countries of operations, such as deferrals of certain tax payments and temporary reductions in social contribution payments. Since we manufacture some of our products for customers in the food and beverage industry, which is considered essential and ensures the continued supply of basic necessities, our supply chain, including raw materials supply and logistics, has generally not been adversely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, and our manufacturing plants were fully or partially exempted from business closure and lockdown orders in most of our countries of operations. As a result, despite a temporary halt of all or part of the operations at our facilities in certain countries, particularly in Asia, in certain South American countries and in South Africa during the first phase of the pandemic, we were able to maintain operations, at different degrees of capacity and for certain production lines, at most of our facilities in Europe and the Americas. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Position and Results of Operations— Principal factors affecting our results of operations—General macroeconomic conditions and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”._ The restrictions and business closures implemented in our countries of operations in response to the COVID-19 pandemic impacted our business marginally in the first quarter of 2020 and more significantly during the second quarter of 2020, which resulted in lower sales volumes, particularly in the spirits end-markets. However, the various measures we implemented in the response to the pandemic and our focus on making our business more resilient and sustainable, coupled with the diversified nature of our end-markets and customer base and our global presence, have allowed us to maintain strong performance in 2020. Following the economic recovery starting in the third and fourth quarter of 2020, we were able to benefit from the gradual lifting of various restrictions on the HORECA industries as well as the tourism sector, and our sales volumes returned to pre-pandemic levels. As a result, while our net revenue in 2020 decreased by €34.5 million, or 5.7%, to €572.0 million from €606.5 million in 2019, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in 2020 decreased by only €2.7 million, or 0.4%, to €603.8 million from €606.5 million in 2019. While for the year ended December 31, 2019, we reported a profit of €14.7 million, for the year ended December 31, 2020, we reported a loss of €5.9 million. In addition, while our Adjusted EBITDA in 2020 decreased by €15.6 million, or 13.7%, to €98.0 million from €113.5 million in 2019, our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates in 2020 decreased by €9.3 million, or 8.2%, compared to 2019. We estimate that in 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a reduction in volumes that negatively impacted our net revenue for the period by approximately €42 million. We estimate that this reduction in volumes and net revenue adversely impacted our Adjusted EBITDA in 2020 by approximately €15 million. In the first three months of 2021, many governments across the world re-introduced restrictive measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19, including travel restrictions and bans and mandatory social distancing for both individuals and businesses, as well as required closures of non-essential businesses, particularly in the HORECA industries as well as the travel sector. Although we and our suppliers and customers have implemented appropriate measures under these restrictions, we believe that the restrictions currently in place have not had the same adverse impact on our business as those restrictions implemented in connection with the first wave of the pandemic in the first and second quarter of 2020. In the first quarter of 2021, the restrictions implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in the HORECA industries had a significant negative effect on the European water and beverage sector (particularly in Italy, Spain and Germany), which heavily relies on on-premises consumption, and we estimate that this resulted in a reduction in volumes compared to the same period in 2020, which adversely impacted our net revenue for the first quarter of 2021 by approximately €8 million. We estimate that this reduction in volumes and net revenue adversely impacted our Adjusted EBITDA by approximately €1 million in the first quarter of 2021. However, this reduction in volumes in the first quarter of 2021 was more than offset by increased sales volumes generated outside of Europe, particularly in the Americas, where revenues grew steadily in the spirits and wine markets, and in Asia, where revenues grew despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Sales volumes outside of Europe also benefitted from customers increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand on off-premises channels such as supermarkets and e-commerce. As a result, while our net revenue for the first quarter of 2021 decreased by €7.6 million, or 5.2%, to €138.3 million from €145.9 million for the first quarter of 2020, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates for the first quarter of 2021 increased by €1.3 million, or 0.9% to 16 ----- €147.2 million from €145.9 million for the first quarter of 2020. While for the three months ended March 31, 2020, we reported a loss of €6.3 million, for the three months ended March 31, 2021, we reported a loss of €0.5 million. In addition, while our Adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter of 2021 increased by €0.2 million, or 0.8%, to €24.3 million from €24.1 million for the first quarter of 2020, our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates for the first quarter of 2021 increased by €2.5 million, or 10.4%, compared to the same period in 2020. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, we reported a loss of €0.2 million. Overall, we estimate that in the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a reduction in sales of approximately €48 million and a negative impact on our Adjusted EBITDA of approximately €15 million. More recently, a resurgence in infections in India during April and May 2021 resulted in the implementation of new restrictions in the country and the renewed shutdown of one of our facilities, which is having a negative impact on our sales volumes in the region. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, all of our plants are operational. The COVID-19 pandemic has been evolving rapidly and we are unable to predict how the outbreak and related government responses may affect our business in the future. We continue to monitor the situation to ensure the safety of our employees, react to any operational developments, logistics disruptions and macroeconomic fluctuations and assess the ongoing impact of developments on our financial condition, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity. We expect our operations to continue to be affected by the COVID-19 pandemic for the foreseeable future and will continue to take the necessary steps to protect our employees and mitigate the risk to our business. _Our estimates regarding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on net revenue and Adjusted EBITDA are mainly related to estimates of volume loss deriving from (i) the temporary closure of, or temporary decrease in production volumes at, our production facilities, (ii) loss of orders from customers for which we are the exclusive supplier and for products whose destination markets were impacted by the various lock-down measures implemented on a country-by-country basis, (iii) bans on alcohol sales imposed by local authorities and (iv) supply chain issues such as, among others, restrictions on import/export, customs duties and freight. These estimates also take into account estimates of increases in sales volume due to (i) higher customer demand for safety stocks in order to avoid possible supply chain issues and (ii) increased sales in certain end- products markets (including the wine and spirits market) through supermarkets as a result of the increase in off- premise consumption. Although we believe the estimates and assumptions we have used to calculate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our net revenue and our Adjusted EBITDA are accurate, this presentation is for illustrative purposes only and does not represent the results that we would have achieved had the COVID-19 pandemic not occurred (which might have been significantly different from the ones we indicate herein). Neither our independent auditors or any other independent auditors or consultants have audited, reviewed, compiled or performed any procedures with respect to this information and, accordingly, investors are strongly cautioned against undue reliance on this information when evaluating an investment decision. These data are inherently subject to risks and uncertainties and may not give an accurate or complete picture of our results of operations for any historical or future period and may not be comparable to our Financial Statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum._ See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—The COVID-19 pandemic could continue to have an _adverse impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, and results of operations, which may be material”._
