Subsection Title: Factors affecting the comparability of operations
Subsubsection Text: _Application of IFRS 16_ The Issuer has applied IFRS 16 starting from January 1, 2019. The application of IFRS 16 increased our current and non-current financial liabilities as a result of the recognition of €17.0 million in lease liabilities. Other operating expenses decreased by €5.4 million from the reduction in lease liabilities due to the application of IFRS 16, while financial expenses in respect of lease liabilities increased by €0.1 million. The application of IFRS 16 had a positive effect of €5.4 million on Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019. The application of IFRS 16 contributed to €5.8 million in amortization and depreciation for the same year. The reclassification of the finance lease assets that were recognized as property, plant and equipment under IAS 17 in previous years and now recognized as “right-of-use assets” under IFRS 16, which has replaced IAS 17, resulted in a decrease of property, plant and equipment by €12.2 million. See also “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Changes to Accounting _Standards—Application of IFRS 16” and note 2(c) “Changes in accounting standards” to the 2019 Financial_ Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors affecting the comparability of operations
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions, divestments and other transactions affecting our scope of consolidation and comparability of our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: During the periods under review, we completed several acquisitions, divestments and other transactions through which we changed the size of our operations and which enabled us to expand into new geographical markets and product markets. In general, such transaction impact the comparability of our results of operations from period to period. In addition, following an acquisition, we may be required to, or may elect to, make significant investments in the acquired assets or companies. The following is a description of the key acquisitions, divestments and other transactions completed during the periods under review. - In February 2021, the Luxembourg subsidiary GCL International S.à r.l. subscribed a capital increase of its associate SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in London and focusing on integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions, for an amount of £1.4 million (equivalent to €1.6 million), increasing the Group’s investment in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd to 30% of its fully diluted share capital. As the company is associated with the Group, it does not fall within the scope of full consolidation. - In September 2020, the German company Guala Closures Deutschland finalized the acquisition of the investment in Guala Closures Turkey as part of the Closurelogic business, after certain previously-agreed conditions were met. - The investment in GCL Pharma S.r.l. was sold in April 2020. - In February 2020, the Luxembourg subsidiary GCL International S.à r.l. formalized the subscription of a 20% interest in the fully diluted share capital of SharpEnd Partnership Ltd. - In February 2020, our German subsidiary, Guala Closures Deutschland, acquired the assets of Closurelogic, a German manufacturer specialized in the production of aluminum closures mainly for beverages and mineral water in glass bottles. - In January 2020, the Group acquired a non-controlling interest in Guala Closures France S.a.s. via capital increase. - Guala Closures East Africa’s new facility was officially inaugurated in Kenya in November 2019 and the company was set up to provide spirits producers in Kenya and the wider east African market with anti-counterfeiting closures featuring the latest technologies. - In January 2019, Guala Closures India Pvt Ltd paid €0.6 million as Axiom’s contingent consideration, as originally set out in the 2017 acquisition contract and in April 2019, Guala Closures India merged Axiom Propack. 83 ----- - In June 2019, Guala Closures Iberica’s assets were transferred to Guala Closures UCP. In addition, in 2019, the remaining assets were sold to third parties and Guala Closures Iberica’s PET facility in Alcalà De Henares (Madrid) was definitively closed. - In June 2019, the Dutch subsidiary Guala Closures International B.V. approved the establishment of a new company in Belarus. The new Minsk facility commenced operations in 2019, continuing the development project to better serve the greater Russian market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Title: General macroeconomic conditions and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic
Subsubsection Text: We are impacted by global economic conditions, including in consumer spending resulting from, among other factors, reduced consumer confidence, falling gross domestic product, rising unemployment rates and uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment. Since early 2020, the worldwide outbreak of COVID-19 and the consequent restrictive measures implemented by the public authorities of the affected countries has had an enormous social impact and a significant impact on general economic performance and on consumption and investments, leading to general uncertainty. We acted immediately to implement all actions necessary to minimize the social and occupational health and safety and financial impacts by defining and implementing flexible and timely action plans. From the outset, we worked tirelessly to ensure the utmost health and safety for our employees, customers and suppliers. We immediately implemented a series of protective measures for our personnel, investing in personal protective equipment to ensure that activities are carried out in accordance with best practices in terms of occupational safety. Our priority is and will remain ensuring the safety of our employees and business continuity. We quickly and responsibly took all steps and safety measures identified by the authorities in the various markets, introducing new protocols, work practices and safety precautions. These safety and prevention measures introduced at the onset of the pandemic remain in place and are continuously updated to comply with the new directives issued by the competent authorities. We also liaise continuously key business partners such as suppliers and customers has been further ramped up with the aim of ensuring business continuity. Specific business continuity plans have been prepared with our key customers. In addition to the measures taken to prevent the spread of COVID-19, such as the distribution of disposable masks and gloves, social distancing between workers, measuring body temperature when entering the workplace and the sanitisation of all premises every two weeks, we entered into a COVID-19 insurance policy with AON, a leading insurance company, covering all our workers worldwide. As part of our focus on the communities in which we operate, we also began production of polycarbonate face shields in Luxembourg, which are sold to businesses in order to finance the free supply of such face shields to healthcare structures in Italy, Spain, France and Luxembourg. To contain the spread, the governments of the various countries introduced increasingly restrictive measures aimed at limiting movement and contact between people, as well as shutting down—sometimes entirely—production activities in sectors classed as non-essential, allowing only essential activities and production to continue, including those of the food, drinks and pharmaceuticals sector in which the group operates, along with logistics services and transport. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, all of our production facilities are operational. Most of our production facilities continued to operate during the entirety of lockdown measures imposed by the respective governments of the countries in which we operate in compliance with the regulations for each country, as the type of activity carried out was classified among those that, except for temporary bans imposed by local governments, could continue to operate during lockdowns. In particular, all of our facilities in Europe remained operational in 2020 during the pandemic. Our facilities in Italy, Spain and France were considered part of the essential supply chain, and remained operational throughout the respective lockdowns. Our facilities in the United Kingdom and the newly acquired facility in Germany also continued to operate throughout the lockdown at reduced capacities. The facilities in Eastern Europe (i.e., Poland, Ukraine, Bulgaria and Belarus) continued to operate at full capacity. Our facilities in Asia are among those that were most affected by the policies implemented by their respective governments to contain the spread of the virus. Our facilities in India stopped operations on March 22, 2020 because of the country’s total lockdown imposed by the local government and resumed operations on April 27, 2020 at reduced capacity because of the national ban on the sale of alcohol until early May and the shuttering of bars and restaurants until September, while the Chinese facility stopped during the period between January 24, 2020 and February 14, 2020. Production at our facilities in the Americas was able to continue during the entire pandemic, with the exception of Argentina where production was suspended for a limited 84 ----- period of time (March 20, 2020 to April 1, 2020), pending authorization to continue activities necessary for the essential supply chain. Our facilities in California (U.S.) and Mexico continued to operate as they are essential to the supply chain, and at sustained rates due to the growth in volumes for brands focused on off-premises and e-commerce sales, which accelerated as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Chilean facility also continued to operate at full capacity and, in Brazil, operations never stopped since the government authorities have not implemented any lockdown measures. In Colombia, during the lockdown period from March 20, 2020 to May 11, 2020, production was converted to produce closures for disinfectants. The production of closures for spirits subsequently resumed, although sales volumes were depressed by the closure of public places of business by local government order until September, 2020. In Oceania, our facilities in Australia and New Zealand continued to operate as they are considered part of essential supply chains. In Africa, our facility in Kenya continued to operate and no local lockdowns were imposed on manufacturing activities, while the facility in South Africa was partially operational and, during the lockdown period from March 26, 2020 to April 30, 2020, only produced for the Water & Beverage and Pharma markets, which the South African government had classified as part of the essential supply chain. Conversely, production was suspended for the spirits market during that period. Our business was only marginally impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in the first quarter of 2020, when the impact was limited to operations in India, China, Argentina and South Africa, where operations were ordered to temporarily shut down, as described above. In the second quarter of 2020, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic was significant, with a loss of sale volumes mainly in our operations in: (i) India, where the government imposed a full lockdown of the country between March 22, 2020 and April 27, 2020 and banned the sale of alcohol from the end of March to the start of May with the shuttering of bars and restaurants until September 2020; (ii) the United Kingdom, where operations are mainly geared more towards global brands and the duty free market; (iii) South Africa, where the partial closure of the facilities between March 26, 2020 and April 30, 2020 meant that it was only possible to produce limited quantities for small niches of the mineral water and beverage markets and the pharmaceutical sector since the sale of alcohol was banned from March 27 to June 1, 2020 and from July 12 to August 17, 2020; (iv) Colombia, where production was converted during the March 20 to May 11, 2020 lockdown to produce closures for disinfectants and public places of business remained shuttered until September 2020; (v) Spain and Italy, which were the European countries hit the hardest by the COVID-19 pandemic. In the second half of 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to impact our business, but less so than in the second quarter and the effects remained mostly concentrated in India, Spain, Italy and Colombia. In terms of our end-markets, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic was felt most heavily in the spirits market, being the sector with the greatest exposure to consumption in the distribution channel represented by bars and restaurants, where net revenue decreased by €55.5 million, or 13.8%, from €402.3 million in 2019 to €346.8 million in 2020 and Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates decreased by €31.5 million, or 7.8%, from €402.3 million in 2019 to €370.7 million in 2020. Severe social distancing restrictions resulted in the almost complete closure of the on-premises channel in the second quarter of 2020 and, in certain countries, in the third quarter as well. The strict limits to travel also adversely affected sales through the duty free channel. Restrictive measures were eased towards the end of the second quarter of 2020, with local governments gradually lifting shuttering orders on the HORECA industries in the third quarter of 2020, but certain restrictions continue to remain in place in certain geographies. Near the end of 2020, as cases rose again in Europe, local authorities ordered new containment measures, which included another round of restrictions on the HORECA industries and the travel sector. We were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic both in terms of decreased sales volumes and in terms of additional costs to ensure the safety of facilities and employees and lower production efficiency as a result of ensuring compliance with safety and social distancing requirements. These were partly offset by measures to contain personnel expense, lower travel expenses and government assistance. We incurred costs directly attributable to the COVID-19 pandemic, which primarily relate to purchasing personal protective equipment (“PPE”) for employees, sanitization and the adaptation of work areas to comply with social distancing requirements. In response to the decrease in sales volumes, we began introducing measures to contain personnel expense in the second quarter of 2020 in order to limit the effect on the profit margin, which resulted in a decrease in personnel expense, mainly in those European countries hit the hardest by the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly the United Kingdom, where the furlough schemes introduced by the government of the United Kingdom allowed us to reduce production on commensurate basis with the lower sales volumes, and in Spain and in Italy, where production was optimized by scheduling holiday leave for employees, concentrating production on the weekdays, avoiding production during the weekend and curtailing bonuses. In India and South Africa, where the extremely severe April 85 ----- lockdowns imposed by the respective governments resulted in a shutdown of approximately one month, personnel expense did not decrease in proportion to the drop in volumes as we also bore the personnel expense during the shutdown period, pursuant to local regulations. We were, however, able to reduce personnel expense in these countries, primarily due to the lower use of temporary workers in India and to fewer overtime hours worked, the greater use of holiday leave and the decrease in employee numbers in South Africa. In China, personnel expense fell as a result of the government’s reduction in social security contributions and the smaller workforce as seven employees resigned during our suspension of between January 24 and February 14, 2020. In Colombia, which was the country where our operations were impacted the most in the South American region, we were able to achieve savings on personnel expense due to the use of holiday leave and the relief granted by the Colombian government which suspended social security contributions for two months. We also received assistance to decrease personnel expense in the United Kingdom, Bulgaria and Argentina, reductions in social security contributions in China and liquidity support measures, particularly the postponement of the deadline for payment of indirect taxes such as VAT in the United Kingdom and the reduction of the VAT rate from 19% to 16% in Germany from July to December 2020. Following a more challenging second quarter in 2020, sales on a like-for-like basis and at constant exchange rates recovered in the third quarter and grew in the fourth quarter of 2020 as the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic started to ease. As a result, while our net revenue in 2020 decreased by €34.5 million, or 5.7%, to €572.0 million from €606.5 million in 2019, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in 2020 decreased by only €2.7 million, or 0.4%, to €603.8 million from €606.5 million in 2019. In the first quarter of 2021, the restrictions implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in the HORECA industries had a significant negative effect on the European water and beverage sector (particularly in Italy, Spain and Germany), which heavily relies on on-premises consumption, and we estimate that this resulted in a reduction in volumes impacting our net revenue by approximately €8 million in such period. However, this loss was more than offset by increased sales volumes generated outside of Europe, particularly in the Americas, where revenues grew steadily in the spirits and wine markets, and in Asia, where revenues grew despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Sales volumes outside of Europe also benefitted from customers increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand on off-premises channels such as supermarkets and e-commerce. As a result, while our net revenue for the first quarter of 2021 decreased by €7.6 million, or 5.2%, to €138.3 million from €145.9 million for the first quarter of 2020, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates for the first quarter of 2021 increased by €1.3 million, or 0.9% to €147.2 million from €145.9 million for the first quarter of 2020. We expect that the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact our operations. See also “Risks _Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—The COVID-19 pandemic could continue to have an adverse impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, and results of operations, which may be material and” and_ “Summary—Recent Developments—Impact of COVID-19”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: Our sales are impacted by changes in the volumes sold based on the different sales mix in product families and customers from one year to another. Certain of our products generate higher sales prices per unit volume and increases in sales of those products impact our average sales price volume unit sold. In particular, we generate the highest sales prices from sales of our specialty closures. In the periods under review, we have focused on increasing our portion of sales from products that have higher sales prices in order to support our margins. This policy contributed to the positive volume/mix effect of €12.0 million in 2020 and €7.3 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. We calculate the volume/mix effect by consolidating period-on-period decreases and increases in sales volumes and changes in product mix (by product families and customers). In our calculation of the volume/mix effect, we also include the currency effect generated by the translation of sales invoiced in a currency other than the local reporting currency, by using the exchange rates of the relevant prior period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: We operate worldwide and have significant non-euro denominated assets, liabilities, revenue and costs. The Group is exposed to currency risk, particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, pounds sterling, Australian dollar, Indian rupee, Ukrainian hryvnia and Polish złoty against the euro, our Group’s reporting currency, as well as against the local reporting currency of each of our subsidiaries. In 86 ----- the year ended December 31, 2020, we derived 15%, 13%, 9% and 5% of our net revenue from sales in U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, Indian rupees and Australian dollars, respectively. We also have exposure to other currencies such as the Brazilian real, Mexican peso, Colombian peso, Argentine peso, South African rand and New Zealand dollar. Certain of these currencies have experienced considerable volatility against the euro in recent years which has affected our results of operations. For example, our reported results of operations were significantly impacted by negative translation effects of the appreciation of the euro in 2020 and in the first quarter of 2021. By way of example to illustrate and quantify the impact of currency exchange rates on our results of operations that was significant over the periods under review, if we applied the average exchange rate of the currencies relevant to our business for the year ended December 31, 2019 to the year ended December 31, 2020, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates was €603.8 million (as compared to net revenue of €572.0 million as reported) and our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates was €104.2 million (as compared to Adjusted EBITDA €98.0 million as reported), respectively. In addition, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been €147.2 million (as compared to net revenue of €138.3 million as reported) and our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates was €26.6 million (as compared to Adjusted EBITDA €24.3 million as reported), respectively. The foregoing impact on our results of operations is mainly due to the translation effect of non-euro revenues generated during the periods and the appreciation of the euro, particularly against the British pound sterling, the Indian rupee, the Ukrainian hryvnia, the Argentinian peso and the Mexican peso. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Measures”. _Transaction risk_ Our exchange rate transaction risks principally relate to purchases of raw materials such as plastic resin and aluminum which have underlying global commodity price indexes denominated in U.S. dollars and are used to varying degrees in the production of all of our products. Our other fixed costs, such as energy, personnel and services related to production are typically denominated in the currency of the relevant production facility (e.g., euro for Italy, złoty for Poland, Brazilian real for Brazil, etc.). Additionally, our customer contracts are typically payable in the currency of the country where the contract is signed, even if the customer may sell spirits or wine for a worldwide consumer base. By locating production in many countries where our customers are based, we seek to match our operating costs with operating revenue in each of the major currencies in which we operate. To the extent that we have incurred expenses that are not denominated in the same currency as related revenue, exchange rate fluctuations have in some cases caused our expenses to increase or decrease as a percentage of total revenue. We also utilize of derivatives to manage movement in aluminum commodity prices. See “—Costs _for raw materials”. Translation Risk_ Our currency translation risk is primarily related to the recognition of revenue generated by subsidiaries during our period-end consolidation and reporting. To prepare the consolidated financial statements of the Group, we translate assets, liabilities, total revenue and expenses into euro at applicable exchange rates. To determine the applicable exchange rate, we use the average exchange rate for statement of comprehensive income items for the period in which we are reporting and the spot period-end exchange rate for balance sheet items. See note 2(d) to the 2020 Financial Statements, as well as the other financial information contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and “—Critical _accounting policies” below. Both revenue and expenses that are denominated in foreign currency are_ converted into euro at the spot rates of the days on which they are recorded. In order to assist management to identify trends and compare performance across regions and business units, we report Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates and Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates basis which is prepared translating the results of a given period in a particular local currency applying the average exchange rate of the local currency in the same period of the previous year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: €263.7 million of our costs in 2019, €243.4 million of our costs in 2020 and €61.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021 were related to raw materials. Raw material costs accounted for 43.5% of our net revenue in 2019, 42.5% of our net revenue in 2020 and 44.4% of our net revenue in the three months ended March 31, 2021. The principal raw materials used in our manufacturing processes are plastic 87 ----- resins and aluminum. We used a total of 35,481 tons of aluminum in 2020 and consumed more than 43,000 tonnes of different types of plastic (PE, PP, PS, PC, PET, etc.). Plastic resins and aluminum accounted for €15.9 million and €26.5 million, or approximately 26% and 43%, respectively, of the cost of all raw materials purchased in the three months ended March 31, 2020; €61.2 million and €110.9 million, or approximately 25% and 46%, respectively, of the cost of all raw materials purchased in 2020 and €79.1 million and €110.7 million, or approximately 30% and 42%, respectively, of the cost of all raw materials purchased in 2019. Raw materials prices can fluctuate substantially over relatively short periods of time. Plastic resins are subject to substantial price fluctuations resulting from shortages in supply and changes in the prices of natural gas, crude oil and other petrochemical products from which resins are produced as well as other factors. Aluminum prices generally exhibit less fluctuation than plastic resins. The price of aluminum has trended upward in recent years. Aluminum prices on the demand-side are driven by end users from the construction, transportation (mainly automotive) and consumer (largely packaging) industries. As we do not typically enter into long-term committed contracts with customers, our contractual arrangements with customers do not contain pass-through mechanisms that would allow or require us to make periodic adjustments in prices to account for commodity price fluctuations. As a result of the foregoing dynamics, generally, any increase in the prices of our raw materials has a direct impact on our production costs and operating margins unless we are able to raise prices. We believe that the relevant raw material prices to illustrate price trends are the LME/ton price for aluminum and for plastic resins, the high density polyethylene (“HDPE”) price and polypropylene and homopolymer price in Europe and the HDPE price and polystyrene price in India. See “Industry Overview”. By way of illustration, in the first three months of 2021, the average prices of plastic resins (HDPE Europe) increased by 10.7% and aluminum prices increased by 12.4%, in each case compared to the first three months of 2020. In 2020, the average prices of plastic resins (HDPE Europe) decreased by 12.1% and aluminum prices decreased by 6.5%, in each case compared to 2019, and in 2019, the average prices of plastic resins increased (HDPE Europe) by 1.7% and the price of aluminum decreased by 9.7% in each case compared to 2018. These increases and decreases contributed to corresponding changes in our total costs. We manage this exposure vis-à-vis customers through proactive renegotiation of prices with customers when raw material prices put pressure on our margins and rely on our long track record of delivering innovative new products and extracting efficiencies through reduction of raw material use to maintain, and even modestly raise, prices during low-commodity periods. Sales of closures are based on contracts and/or purchase orders that mean that at least part of any increase in the prices of raw materials can be transferred to our customers, when the contracts provide for periodic price adjustments. If this is not possible, we are able to manufacture similar closures due to our technological expertise using different materials mix that ensures, nonetheless, product quality. Given our wide product range, we can offer customers various solutions (using different materials) and to direct their choices to the higher value added luxury lines, thus better absorbing any raw material price increases without significantly affecting margins. We also employ commodity derivatives for aluminum to hedge a certain portion of purchases. On average, 15% of our aluminum costs in the year ended December 31, 2020 and in the three months ended March 31, 2021 were related to purchases of aluminum ingots on the London Metal Exchange, through forward contracts and spot transactions, while the remaining aluminum costs consist primarily of costs incurred in conversion and processing which are typically contractually fixed for a short period of time. As we typically purchase aluminum based on contracts that set prices by reference to the aluminum quotations on the London Metal Exchange in U.S. dollars, which are converted into euro at the average exchange rate at the month of purchase, we seek to reduce our exposure to the risks associated with aluminum price fluctuations by entering into forward contracts with brokers operating on the London Metal Exchange, whereby we purchase aluminum at a fixed price to protect our operating margins from price volatility. We have not historically hedged the risk of fluctuations in the purchase price of plastics as these raw materials are not listed on international markets. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Our business is _subject to fluctuations in the price and availability of raw materials” and note 38(b) to the 2020 Financial_ Statements. Other methods of commodity risk mitigation include the careful selection of our suppliers, in particular for plastics, where we seek out suppliers that match our pricing, quality and reliability of supply criteria. We have not experienced any significant difficulties over the past few years in obtaining sufficient quantities of the raw materials required for our production. We also continually seek to implement innovative product and process solutions aimed at reducing consumption of raw materials. 88 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Demand and activity levels in the spirits and wine end-markets
Subsubsection Text: We sell our products primarily to customers operating in the spirits and wine end-markets in various geographies around the world. In the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, these markets combined represented 84% and 81%, respectively, of our net revenue. Accordingly, our sales volumes and results of operations depend to a significant extent on the level of activity and industry trends in these end-markets. For spirits producers, packaging and brand are key elements in product identification and differentiation. As a result, demand in this end-market is primarily focused on high quality, customized and reliable products that enable customers to better differentiate and position their brands against their competitors. We believe that demand for safety closures in the spirits end-market will continue to grow, particularly in emerging countries where premium brands are penetrating further and where the risk of counterfeiting is higher. Technological solutions, sustainability and zero-environmental impact packaging are also becoming increasingly important in both the spirits and wine end-markets. Spirits and wine producers as well as their end-customers are increasingly looking for products with fully integrated technological functionalities that enhance product safety and customer experience, as well as products with a reduced impact on the environment, that are recyclable and made with a higher share of recycled materials. We believe that these will be the key growth and demand trends for our products in the spirits and wine end-markets going forward.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Title: The overall level of, and the interest rates payable on, our indebtedness
Subsubsection Text: During the periods under review, we had significant debt service obligations related to the Existing Notes. As of March 31, 2021, our current and non-current financial liabilities amounted, respectively, to €24.4 million and €504.4 million, for a total amount of €528.9 million, and, excluding unamortized transaction costs and the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors and financial liabilities related to the Market Warrants, our total financial liabilities amounted to €500.9 million. For information relating to the interest rates payable on our financial indebtedness, see note 30 to the 2020 Financial Statement and note 24 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. Prior to and following the Refinancing, we had and will continue to have a significant amount of indebtedness. As of March 31, 2021, As Adjusted Total Financial Debt would have been €500.7 million (excluding unamortized transaction costs, the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors, financial liabilities related to the Market Warrants and any amounts that we may draw under the Revolving Credit Facility in connection with the Refinancing). See “Capitalization”.

Subsection Title: Principal factors affecting our results of operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by seasonal factors for certain product categories (specifically, roll-on for wine closures and roll-on closures for mineral water), which generally results in an increase in the sales volumes in the second half of each year and, especially, during holiday periods, which also vary according to hemisphere. Our sales particularly correspond to variations relating to consumption and/or production of wine in such regions. Accordingly, our quarterly results of operations will vary from quarter to quarter due to these seasonal factors, and do not contribute evenly to the annual results. 89 -----

Subsubsection Text: _Safety Closures_ Revenue from safety closures decreased by €1.6 million, or 2.9%, from €54.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €53.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was 92 ----- mainly due to a negative translation impact of €(5.1) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates from safety closures increased by €3.5 million, or 6.4%, to €58.2 million from €54.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was mainly due to higher sales volumes in the Americas and Asia, which more than offset lower sales volumes in Europe. _Luxury Closures_ Revenue from luxury closures decreased by €0.4 million, or 5.2%, from €7.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €7.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was mainly due to a negative translation impact of €(0.6) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 from luxury closures increased by €0.2 million, or 2.5%, to €7.9 million from €7.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The slight increase was mainly due to higher sales volumes in the Mexico, which were almost entirely offset by lower sales volumes in Europe. _Roll-on Closures_ Revenue from roll-on closures decreased by €4.6 million, or 9.4%, from €48.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €44.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, with a negative translation impact of €(2.1) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 from roll-on closures decreased by €2.5 million, or 5.2%, to €46.3 million from €48.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly due to lower sales as a result of the restrictions implemented in the HORECA industries in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, which mostly impacted the water & beverages market in Europe, particularly Italy, Spain and Germany. _Roll-on for Wine Closures_ Revenue from the sale of roll-on for wine closures increased by €1.2 million, or 4.3%, from €28.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €29.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite negative translation impact of €(0.8) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 from wine closures increased by €2.1 million, or 7.4%, to €30.1 million from €28.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was mainly due to higher sales volumes in Poland, the Americas and Germany, where we started to operate in February 2020, which were partly offset by lower sales volumes in Oceania and the United Kingdom. _Other Revenue_ Other revenue decreased by €2.2 million, or 32.8%, from €6.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €4.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, with a negative translation impact of €(0.3) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 from other closures decreased by €1.9 million or 29%, to €4.7 million from €6.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly due to the sale of GCL Pharma in April 2020. _Net revenue by geographical segment_ The following table provides a breakdown of net revenue by main geographical segment (i.e., based on the geographical location of the subsidiary of the Group that records the revenue rather than the location of the customer) for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021: _Europe_ Net revenue from operations in Europe decreased by €11.1 million, or 12.2%, from €91.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €80.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, with a negative translation impact of €(2.4) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 of this region decreased by €8.7 million, or 9.6%, to €82.5 million from €91.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease is mainly due to the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the first three months of 2021, due to the restrictions implemented in the HORECA industries, especially in Spain, Italy and Germany. In particular, the total decrease in net revenue generated in these three countries accounted for €8.8 million in the first three months of 2021. _Americas_ Net revenue from operations in the Americas increased by €3.5 million, or 14.4%, from €24.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €27.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a significant negative translation impact of €(4.9) million, recorded mainly in Mexico, Argentina and Brazil. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 of this region increased by €8.4 million, or 34.6%, to €32.7 million from €24.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase is mainly due to the positive net impact on sales volumes from the COVID-19 pandemic in the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was driven primarily by customers increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand on off-premises channels such as supermarkets and e-commerce, particularly in North America, which more than offset the negative impact on volumes due to the restrictions implemented in response to the pandemic, including in the in HORECA industries. _Asia_ Net revenue from operations in Asia increased by €0.5 million, or 2.9%, from €17.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €17.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a significant negative translation impact of €(1.6) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 of this region increased by €2.1 million, or 12.5%, to €19.3 million from €17.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase is mainly due to revenues growing in the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020 when they were already partially impacted by COVID-19. The estimated net impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in Asia was immaterial. _Oceania_ Net revenue from operations in Oceania decreased by €0.8 million, or 8.8%, from €9.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €8.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a positive translation impact of €0.5 million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 of this region decreased by €1.3 million or 13.8%, to €7.9 million from €9.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease is mainly due to the decrease in sales volumes resulting from the slow-down of the domestic wine market, the steady increase in exports of bulk wine and the recent reduction in wine exports to China. These factors have resulted in a supply surplus in the region, which led to greater competition and downward pressure on sales prices. In light of these negative trends, 94 ----- we started the process of reorganizing our business in Australia in order to align its ongoing costs with the changed market conditions, including by reducing headcount. _Africa_ Net revenue from operations in Africa increased by €0.3 million, or 7.3%, from €4.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €4.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a negative translation impact of €(0.4) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 of this region increased by €0.7 million or 17.8%, to €4.8 million from €4.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase is mainly due to the positive net impact on sales volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to a negative impact in the three months ended March 31, 2020. This positive net impact was mainly due to customers increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand on off-premises channels such as supermarkets and e-commerce, which more than offset the negative impact on volumes due to the restrictions implemented in response to the pandemic, including in the HORECA industries.

Subsubsection Text: _Europe_ Net revenue from operations in Europe decreased by €12.9 million, or 3.6%, from €358.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €345.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a negative translation impact of €(6.1) million. The decrease is mainly due to the sale of some of the Spanish assets of the PET division to third parties and the sale of GCL Pharma S.r.l. in the second quarter of 2020 and a decrease in sales as a result of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in relation to operations in the United Kingdom, Spain and Italy, which had a negative impact on our net revenue in Europe. The decrease was only partially offset by the positive contribution of €30.9 million in revenue from the acquisition of Closurelogic. _Americas_ Net revenue from operations in the Americas increased by €2.7 million, or 2.5%, from €109.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €112.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, despite the negative translation impact of €(18.4) million recorded, mainly in Mexico, Argentina and Brazil. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020 increased by €21.1 million, or 19.2%, to €130.8 million from €109.8 million in 2019. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in this region led to significant growth in sales in the North American spirits market following the increase in off-premises demand and penetration in new businesses/customers, which had a positive impact, in Mexico due to greater sales in the U.S. market, which had a positive impact of €0.7 million, and the increase in sales in the Chilean wine market. _Asia_ Net revenue from operations in Asia decreased by €20.7 million, or 25.8%, from €80.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €59.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020 decreased by €16.7 million, or 20.8%, to €63.5 million from €80.1 million in 2019. This decrease is mainly due to the drop in sales after the shutdown of facilities in India and China during the lockdown in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and operations that were at less than full capacity in the subsequent months because of the contraction in domestic consumption following the ban on the sale of alcohol between the end of March and the start of May and the shuttering of bars and restaurants until September in India, causing an overall negative impact on sale volume in Asia compared to 2019 of €17.2 million. In addition, the decrease was partially due to the transfer of some of the volumes previously produced by our Indian subsidiary to the business start-up in Kenya. _Oceania_ Net revenue from operations in Oceania decreased by €1.9 million, or 4.7%, from €40.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €38.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, including the negative translation impact of €(1.1) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020 decreased by €0.8 million, or 1.9%, to €39.3 million from €40.1 million in 2019. Sales in this region are mainly tied to the wine segment which has in recent years has been impacted by exports of unbottled wine that is then bottled in the country of destination. The delay in the bottling season due to the COVID-19 pandemic has partly eroded sales volumes in 2020. 103 ----- _Africa_ Net revenue from operations in Africa decreased by €1.7 million, or 9.3%, from €18.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €16.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a negative translation impact of €(2.2) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020 increased by €0.5 million, or 2.6%, to €18.8 million from €18.3 million in 2019. The decrease in revenue was also due to operations in South Africa and, in particular, the partial suspension of production from March 26 to April 30 following the lockdown imposed by the local authorities and the ban on the sale of alcohol between March 27 and June 1 and between July 12 and August 17. Specifically, production of closures for the spirits market in South Africa was suspended by the South African government and production was only allowed for the water & beverage and pharma markets that were designated as essential, causing an overall negative impact of €(2.5) million. Despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, operations in Kenya continue to grow at sustained rates, partly offsetting the downturn in South Africa.

Subsubsection Text: Personnel expense increased by €4.6 million, or 3.6%, from €125.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €129.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, mainly as a result of the net impact from the change in the scope of consolidation from 2019 to 2020. Net personnel expense related to the acquisition of Closurelogic net of the disposal of GCL Pharma increased personnel expense by €7.2 million. Excluding this impact, personnel expense primarily due to the cost containment policies that we implemented in the second and third quarters of 2020 to mitigate the impact of the lower sale volumes on profitability following the global outbreak of COVID-19. This resulted in a decrease in personnel expense, mainly in those European countries that experienced more severe effects from the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly the United Kingdom, where the furlough schemes introduced by the government of the United Kingdom allowed us to reduce production on commensurate basis with the lower sales volumes, and in Spain and Italy, where production was optimized by scheduling holiday leave for employees, concentrating production on the weekdays, avoiding production during the weekend and curtailing bonuses. In India and South Africa, where the extremely severe April lockdowns imposed by the respective governments resulted in a shutdown of approximately one month, personnel expense did not decrease in proportion to the drop in volumes as we also bore the personnel expense during the shutdown period, pursuant to local regulations. We were, however, able to reduce personnel expense in these countries, primarily due to the lower use of temporary workers in India and to fewer overtime hours worked, the greater use of holiday leave and a decrease in in the number of employees in South Africa.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the consummation of the Transactions, our historical liquidity requirements have arisen primarily from the need to meet our debt service requirements, to finance our operations and to fund capital expenditures, product research and development and acquisitions. We expect that these will continue to be our primary liquidity requirements. In connection with the Offers, the results of which were announced by SPSI on June 7, 2021, the change of control provision in our Existing Notes were triggered and the Issuer will be required in accordance with the provisions of the indenture governing the Existing Notes to make an offer to holders of the Existing Notes to repurchase any or all of their Existing Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount of such Existing Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, unless the Issuer elects to redeem all of the outstanding Existing Notes at par prior to the date on which the Issuer is required to make such an offer. There is committed financing in place in order to fund the redemption, if required. We will apply the proceeds from the issuance of the Notes, together with cash on balance sheet, to redeem the Existing Notes and pay accrued interest thereon, repay amounts outstanding under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, and pay fees and expenses associated with the Refinancing. See “Use of Proceeds”. Our primary sources of liquidity are cash flows from operations and 109 ----- borrowings from financial institutions under our credit facilities, particularly the €80.0 million Revolving Credit Facility that will be entered into in connection with the Transactions. As of March 31, 2021, our current and non-current financial liabilities amounted, respectively, to €24.4 million and €504.4 million, for a total amount of €528.9 million, and, excluding unamortized transaction costs and the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors and financial liabilities related to the Market Warrants, our total financial liabilities amounted to €500.9 million. As of March 31, 2021, as adjusted for the Refinancing our As Adjusted Total Financial Debt would have been €500.7 million (excluding unamortized transaction costs, the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors, financial liabilities related to the Market Warrants and any amounts that we may draw under the Revolving Credit Facility in connection with the Refinancing). From time to time we engage in the sale of our trade receivables on the basis of without-recourse factoring arrangements in order to support our working capital and liquidity needs. The COVID-19 pandemic partly contributed to the decrease in trade receivables from €104.1 million as of December 31, 2019 to €92.6 million as of December 31, 2020 and €97.2 million as of March 31, 2021, which, in turn, resulted in a reduction in the use of without-recourse factoring from €28.2 million as of December 31, 2019 to €26.7 million as of December 31, 2020 and €20.8 million as of March 31, 2021. Our current and prospective liquidity is monitored constantly. We have not experienced any significant changes in terms of collection or payment activities directly or indirectly related to the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that the available liquidity is adequate to cover current and prospective operating needs and debt service obligations. However, we face significant risks to our liquidity. For instance, our business may not generate sufficient cash flows from operations or future debt and equity financing may not be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including under the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility” and “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to our Indebtedness—We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to meet our debt obligations”._ We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity also include: - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a decline in EBIT from our operations, which could be caused by a downturn in our performance or in the industry as a whole; - the failure of our customers to make payments due to us; - a delay by our customers to make payments due to us; - any further significant impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and government responses related thereto; and - the need to fund maintenance capital expenditures. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduced or delay our business activities and capital expenditures; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity financing; and/or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. We may not accomplish any of the foregoing alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility and any future debt may limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. 110 -----

Subsubsection Text: (1) The comparative figures for the three months ended March 31, 2020 were restated to reflect the effects of the completion of the purchase price accounting procedure related to the acquisition of Closurelogic business by Guala Closures Deutschland GmbH in February 2020. _Cash Flows from (used in) Operating Activities_ Net cash flows from (used in) operating activities changed by €11.5 million from an outflow of €1.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to an inflow of €9.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, primarily due to (i) the €4.3 million increase in profit before taxation compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020, (ii) the €11.1 million reduction in negative changes in trade receivables, payables and inventory compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020 and (iii) the €0.7 million decrease in taxes compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. These positive effects were partly offset by the €3.6 million decrease in net financial expenses and the €0.3 million increase in gains on the sale of non-current assets and the €0.2 million decrease in other operating items. Net cash flows from operating activities decreased €9.5 million from €86.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €77.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to the decrease of: (i) €21.2 million of higher loss before taxation partially offset by higher net financial expenses of €6.7 million and higher depreciation and amortization of €1.8 million; and (ii) €5.9 million in changes in trade receivables, payables and inventory. These decreases were partly offset by the €3.2 million improvement in cash flows for taxes, mainly due to the deferral of payment of indirect taxes such as VAT in the United Kingdom as part of liquidity support measures introduced by the government of the United Kingdom in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. _Cash Flows used in Investing Activities_ Net cash flows used in investing activities decreased by €11.9 million from €22.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €10.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, primarily due to lower outflows for M&A activities in the three months ended March 31, 2021, which consisted of €1.6 million for the acquisition of an additional 10% in the share capital of the Group’s UK associate SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., compared to €12.2 million for the acquisition of Closurelogic’s business in Germany and €0.9 million for the subscription of the first minority stake of 20% in the share capital of SharpEnd Partnership Ltd. in the three months ended March 31, 2020. In addition, cash flows used for Net Capital Expenditure decreased by €0.5 million from €9.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €9.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021. Net cash flows used in investing activities increased by €1.9 million from €36.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €37.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to M&A activities which generated net negative outflows of €6.2 million in 2020, including €12.4 million for the acquisition of Closurelogic’s assets in Germany and Turkey and €0.9 million to acquire the non-controlling interest in the UK company SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., which was partly offset by the €7.1 million generated by the sale of the equity investment in GCL Pharma as compared to outflows for M&A of only €0.6 million in 2019 for the deferred payment of the Indian company Axiom Propack. In addition, cash flows used for Net Capital Expenditure decreased by €3.7 million from €35.4 million in 2019 to €31.8 million in 2020. _Cash Flows generated (used in) Financing Activities_ Net cash flows generated (used) in financing activities changed by €25.2 million from an inflow of €16.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to an outflow of €9.1 million for the three months 111 ----- ended March 31, 2021. This change was primarily due to higher proceeds from new borrowings to support the working capital increase and investing activities completed in the first three months of 2020. Net cash flows used in financing activities decreased by €14.3 million, from €43.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €29.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease was due to the higher proceeds from new borrowings related to the acquisition of Closurelogic’s assets in Germany and Turkey and higher repayment of leases. _Dividends_ Pursuant to Article 20.2 of the Issuer’s by-laws, the net profit resulting from the financial results will be distributed among the Issuer’s shareholders, after deduction of the 5% to be allocated to the legal reserve, until this reserve will have reached 1/5 of the share capital, pursuant to what is resolved by the Board of Directors. Moreover, pursuant to Article 20.3 of the Issuer’s by-laws, the Board of Directors of the Issuer may, during the course of a financial year, distribute interim dividends pursuant to the law in force from time to time. In 2020, we made a distribution of dividends to non-controlling investors in the amount of €6.9 million. The ability of the Issuer to distribute dividends to its shareholders will be subject to any contractual restrictions, including the restricted payments covenants in the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility.

Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditure and investments relate primarily to extending, upgrading and maintaining our production facilities, research and development activities and investments in new technologies as well as expenditures to comply with applicable environmental, health and safety (“EHS”) law and regulations and sustainability. We define Net Capital Expenditure as Acquisitions of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets less Proceeds from sale of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets in our Statement of cash flows. On average, our Net Capital Expenditure represents between 5.5% and 6.5% of our net revenue. For purposes of this presentation, we also present Growth Capital Expenditure (which includes investments in NFC technologies), Maintenance Capital Expenditure and EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure. Growth Capital Expenditure includes discretionary investments to expand our geographical footprint or increase our manufacturing capacity and capabilities and cost savings and efficiency projects to optimize our operations, equipment and footprint. Growth Capital Expenditure also includes certain discretionary investments in the design, development and production of solutions with embedded NFC technologies. Maintenance Capital Expenditure includes critical ordinary course investments in tangible and fixed assets to ensure the continuing operation of our asset base. EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure includes expenditures related to applicable EHS laws and regulations and sustainability. 113 ----- This capital expenditure breakdown is based on management accounts and we do not intend to continue reporting Growth Capital Expenditure, Maintenance Capital Expenditure or EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure on a separate basis going forward. During the three months ended March 31, 2021, the Group directed most capital expenditure specifically towards Europe (the facilities in Poland, Italy, Germany, Ukraine and Bulgaria), Asia (particularly India) and in Africa (especially in Kenya). Net Capital Expenditure in Italy was mainly directed at increasing production capacity, new product development and extraordinary plant maintenance. Net Capital Expenditure in Poland was mainly aimed at increasing production capacity. Net Capital Expenditure in Ukraine was mainly directed at increasing production capacity, plant safety and extraordinary plant maintenance. Furthermore, in Europe, Net Capital Expenditure comprised investments in new product development at our facilities in Bulgaria and our research center in Luxembourg, as well as significant maintenance expenditure for our plants in the United Kingdom and Ukraine. Net Capital Expenditure in Africa mainly related to extraordinary maintenance of our plants in South Africa and the increase in production capacity of our plant in Kenya. Net Capital Expenditure in Oceania mainly focused on Australia, where we invested in production efficiencies. Net Capital Expenditure in 2020, totaling €31.8 million, mainly related to work on plant and machinery to develop new products and expand production capacity and efficiency, in addition to considerable investments in EHS and sustainability. During the year, the Group directed most capital expenditure specifically towards Europe (the facilities in Italy, Poland and Ukraine), Asia (particularly India) and South America (especially Mexico). Net Capital Expenditure in Italy was mainly directed at increasing production capacity, new product development and extraordinary plant maintenance. Net Capital Expenditure in Poland, was mainly aimed at increasing production capacity. Net Capital Expenditure in Ukraine, was primarily aimed at increasing production capacity, plant safety and extraordinary plant maintenance. Furthermore, in Europe, Net Capital Expenditure comprised investments in new product development at the facilities in France and Bulgaria and the research center in Luxembourg as well as for extraordinary maintenance on plants in the United Kingdom, Spain and Germany. Net Capital Expenditure in Asia was targeted, in particular, at our Indian facilities where we invested in extraordinary plant maintenance and new product development. Net Capital Expenditure in the Americas was mainly focused on our Mexican facility, with projects for plant safety and extraordinary maintenance. We also made smaller investments at all the other facilities across the region. In Africa, Net Capital Expenditure related mainly to extraordinary maintenance on plants in South Africa and the increase in production capacity at the facility in Kenya. In Australia and New Zealand, Net Capital Expenditure mainly consisted of small maintenance expenditures. Net Capital Expenditure in 2019 amounted to €35.4 million, mainly related to plant and machinery and covered, although to differing extents, all five continents where the group operates. In particular, capital expenditure was concentrated in Europe and mostly related to the facilities in Italy, Ukraine and the United Kingdom. Net Capital Expenditure in Italy mainly related to the development of new products 114 ----- and the increase in production capacity, with a particular focus on the mineral water market and the extraordinary maintenance of facilities. Net Capital Expenditure in Ukraine mainly related to the development of new products, the increase in production capacity and the safety of the production facilities. Considerable Net Capital Expenditure in extraordinary maintenance and safety was made at the facilities of Guala Closures UCP, acquired in December 2018. Net Capital Expenditure at the Polish facility in 2019 related to the construction of the new warehouse and the development of production capacity and the extraordinary maintenance of the plant and machinery used. At the French facility, Net Capital Expenditure focussed on the reorganization of production with a new layout and new machinery. Finally, in Europe, Net Capital Expenditure went to new product development and increasing the production capacity of the our facilities in Spain and Bulgaria. We also continued to make capital expenditures at the Luxembourg research department for the development of new products and in streamlining and increasing production capacity. In Asia, substantial Net Capital Expenditure was undertaken at our facilities in India, particularly in relation to the expansion of the Dharwad production facility during 2019. In the Americas, Net Capital Expenditure mainly focused on the our facility in Mexico with projects to cut production costs and increase production capacity and smaller capital expenditure was also made in all the other facilities in the area. In Africa, most Net Capital Expenditure was directed at Guala Closures East Africa’s Kenyan facility, where production began in February 2019. In Australia and New Zealand only small investments of immaterial amounts were made for maintenance. We expect that our Net Capital Expenditure as a percentage of our net revenue for the year ending December 31, 2021 will be broadly in line with our Net Capital Expenditure for 2020.

Subsubsection Text: The Group accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when the acquired set of activities and assets meets the definition of a business and control is transferred to the Group. In determining whether a particular set of activities and assets is a business, the Group assesses whether the set of assets and activities acquired includes, at a minimum, an input and substantive process and whether the acquired set has the ability to produce outputs. The Group has an option to apply a “concentration test” that permits a simplified assessment of whether an acquired set of activities and assets is not a business. The optional concentration test is met if substantially all of the fair value of the gross assets acquired is concentrated in a single identifiable asset or group of similar identifiable assets. The consideration transferred in the acquisition is generally measured at fair value, as are the identifiable net assets acquired. Any goodwill that arises is tested annually for impairment. Any gain on a bargain purchase is recognized in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs are expensed as incurred, except if related to the issue of debt or equity securities. The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing relationships. Such amounts are generally recognized in the profit or loss statement. Any contingent consideration is measured at fair value as at the date of acquisition. If an obligation to pay contingent consideration that meets the definition of a financial instrument is classified as equity, then it is not remeasured and settlement is accounted for within equity. Otherwise, other contingent consideration is remeasured at fair value at each reporting date and subsequent changes in the fair value of the contingent consideration are recognized in the profit or loss statement. If share-based payment awards (replacement awards) are required to be exchanged for awards held by the acquirer’s employees (acquirer’s awards), then all or a portion of the amount of the acquirer’s replacement awards is included in measuring the consideration transferred in the business combination. This determination is based on the market-based measure of the replacement awards compared with the market-based measure of the acquirer’s awards and the extent to which the replacement awards relate to pre-combination service. 117 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of each reporting date, the Group reviews the carrying amounts of its non-financial assets, except for inventories and deferred tax assets, to determine whether there is any indication of impairment. If any such indication exists, then the asset’s recoverable amount is estimated. Goodwill is tested annually for impairment. For impairment testing, assets are grouped together into the smallest group of assets that generates cash inflows from continuing use that are largely independent of the cash inflows of other assets or cash generating units (“CGUs”). Goodwill arising from a business combination is allocated to CGUs or groups of CGUs that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the combination. The recoverable amount of an asset or CGU is the greater of its value in use and its fair value less costs to sell. Value in use is based on the estimated future cash flows, discounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable amount. Impairment losses are recognized in the profit or loss statements. They are allocated first to reduce the carrying amount of any goodwill allocated to the CGU, and then to reduce the carrying amounts of the other assets in the CGU on a pro rata basis. An impairment loss in respect of goodwill is not reversed. With respect to other assets, an impairment loss is reversed only to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortization, if no impairment loss had been recognized.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes comprise current and deferred tax. They are recognized in profit or loss except to the extent that they relate to a business combination, or items recognized directly in equity or in other comprehensive income. Current tax comprises the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable profit or loss for the year and any adjustment to tax payable or receivable in respect of previous years. It is measured using tax rates enacted or substantially enacted at the reporting date. Current tax also includes any tax arising from dividends as well as any tax arising from dividends and any interest and penalties imposed by the tax authorities following their review of the tax position of previous years which found a difference in tax due. Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax is not recognized for: temporary differences in the initial recognition of assets or liabilities in a transaction that is not a business combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss; temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, associates and joint arrangements, to the extent that the Group is able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences and it is probable that they will not reverse in the foreseeable future; taxable temporary differences arising on the initial recognition of goodwill. Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses and unused tax credits to the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. Deferred tax assets are reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related tax benefit will be realised. Deferred tax is measured at the tax rates that are expected to be applied to temporary differences when they reverse, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date. The measurement of deferred tax reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner in which the Group expects, at the reporting date, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and liabilities. The income tax related to dividends are recognized when the dividend is approved. In determining the amount of current and deferred tax, the Group takes into account the impact of uncertain tax positions and whether additional taxes and interest may be due. The Group believes that its 118 ----- accruals for tax liabilities are adequate for all open tax years based on its assessment of many factors, including interpretations of tax law and prior experience. This assessment relies on estimates and assumptions and may involve a series of judgments about future events. New information may become available that causes the Group to change its judgment regarding the adequacy of existing tax liabilities; such changes to tax liabilities will affect tax expense in the period that such a determination is made.

Subsubsection Text: Provisions include certain or probable costs and charges, the amount or due date of which is unknown at the end of the financial year. A provision is recognized when (i) a company has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, (ii) it is probable that an outflow from the company of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation and (ii) a reliable estimate can be made of the obligation. The provisions are stated as the best estimate of the expenditure required to settle the obligation at the reporting date or to transfer it to a third party at that date. If the impact of discounting the time value of money is significant, the provision is determined by discounting expected future cash flows using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects the current market assessment of the time value of money. Where discounting is used, the increase in the provision due to the passage of time is recognized as interest expense.
