Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: This risk relates to the effect of fluctuations in exchange rates on sales and purchases in currencies other than the functional currencies of the various Group entities. The Group is exposed to currency risk, particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, British pound, Australian dollar, Indian rupee, Ukrainian hryvnia and Polish zloty. Interest on loans is denominated in the currency of the cash flows generated by the group’s underlying transactions. The risk of exchange fluctuations is managed by using currency hedges from time to time when significant differences between cost and revenue in foreign currency were noticed and such differences were hedged through currency swaps. These provided for the purchase/sale of agreed amounts in foreign currency at a set exchange rate against the euro. The impact of exchange rates fluctuations on our results of operations is significant. For more information, see “—Principal factors affecting our results of operations—Fluctuations in currency exchange _rates” and note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: This is the risk that a customer or the counterparty to a financial instrument is unable to meet an obligation, leading to a financial loss. These risks arise mainly in relation to trade receivables and financial investments. The Group’s exposure to credit risk depends largely on each customer’s specific characteristics. The demographics of the Group’s customer portfolio, including the segment insolvency risk and the country risk, have an impact on the credit risk. See note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information. The Group accrues a loss allowance equal to the estimated losses on trade and other loans and receivables. This allowance comprises both the recognition of impairment losses for material individual amounts and the recognition of collective impairment for similar groups of assets to cover losses already incurred but not yet identified. The collective impairment losses are calculated on the basis of historical payment statistics. Most of the Group’s trade receivables are due from leading operators of the alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverage segment. Most of its trading relationships are with long-standing customers. The Group reduces its credit risk using supplier financing lines made available by its main customers and factoring without recourse part of its trade receivables. 119 ----- The Group’s historical figures indicate a modest amount of credit losses. The risk is fully covered by the corresponding loss allowance recognized in the Financial Statements. There are no cases of particularly concentrated credit risk in geographical terms.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: This risk relates to the Group’s ability to meet its obligations arising from financial liabilities. The Group’s approach to liquidity management is to ensure adequate funds are always available to meet its obligations at the expiry dates, both in normal conditions and at times of financial difficulty, without incurring borrowing expense at terms higher than market conditions. The Group generally ensures there is sufficient cash and cash equivalents to cover forecast short-term operating expenses, including those related to financial liabilities. Contingent effects arising from extreme situations that cannot reasonably be forecast, such as natural disasters, are excluded from the above. The aim of the Group’s financing strategy is to maintain a well-balanced maturity profile for liabilities to thereby reduce the refinancing risk. Historically, the Group has always met its obligations on time and has been able to re-finance indebtedness before its expiry. See note 30, 31 and 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk relates to volatility of the market rates that determine the interest expense paid on outstanding loans. The Group is currently exposed to interest rate risk as almost all of its financial liabilities is subject to the payment of interest at floating rates subject to short-term repricing, including borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and indebtedness under the Existing Notes. Any borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility will also be subject to such interest rate risk. The Group does not currently deem it necessary to hedge the portion of the liability subject to interest rate risk given the current EURIBOR parameters. As of December 31, 2020, we estimated that a hypothetical increase of 100 basis point in the interest rate on our floating rate borrowings could have the net effect of increasing our cash outflows for the year ended December 31, 2020 by €7.1 million. See note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: As a result of the nature of its activities, the Group is exposed to the risk of fluctuations in the purchase price of raw materials, particularly plastics and aluminum. The risk of fluctuations in the purchase price of plastics has not been hedged, as these raw materials were not listed on international markets (the London Metal Exchange). However, the risk of fluctuations in the purchase price of aluminum is partly hedged based on market needs and outlook through derivatives that set the forward purchase price as described under “—Principal factors affecting our results of _operations—Costs for raw materials”._ See note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s objectives in capital management are to create value for shareholders, safeguard the Group’s future and support its future development. Therefore, the Group seeks to maintain a sufficient level of capitalization, while providing shareholders with satisfactory returns and ensuring access to external sources of financing at acceptable terms, including by maintaining an adequate rating. The Group monitors its debt to equity ratio on an ongoing basis, particularly in terms of net indebtedness and cash flows generated by operating activities. The Board of Directors carefully monitors the balance between greater returns through the right level of indebtedness and the advantages of a sound financial position. To achieve these objectives, the Group strives to continuously make its operations more profitable. The Board of Directors monitors the return on capital, being total equity attributable to owners of the Group’s parent and the amount of dividends to be distributed to holders of ordinary shares. There were no changes in the Group’s approach to capital management during the period under review. 120 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Guala is a world leader in the production and sale of aluminium and plastic closures for the beverage industry. Guala primarily manufactures closures for global premium and local brands in the global spirits and Roll-on for wine markets. It also manufactures closures for water and other beverages as well as for vegetable oils and other condiments. Packaging (bottle, label and closure) is an important consideration for spirits and Roll-on for wine producers worldwide and is increasingly becoming a significant point of differentiation as spirits and Roll-on for wine producers compete to attract consumers. The proliferation of spirits and Roll-on for wines available to the consumer at the retail level has made packaging increasingly important in conveying quality and brand image. Further, consolidation within the spirits and Roll-on for wine industry and the formation of several major international spirits and Roll-on for wine conglomerates with substantial advertising and marketing budgets has led to an increased emphasis on branding, especially as international spirits and Roll-on for wine producers increasingly pursue a strategy of “premiumization” and protection of their brands. Increasingly, local or regional producers in the emerging markets are also focusing on their packaging content in order to build new points of differentiation between their brands and competing brands. As such, spirits and Roll-on for wine producers, both in respect of global brands and local brands, work closely with packaging suppliers, including closures manufacturers, in order to design the desired image for their product and to help differentiate each product from its competitors. Closures have today become part of the brand image for renowned global spirits and Roll-on for wines, allowing an end consumer to identify his or her favourite brand and to build a relationship with the brand. The look and feel of a product’s closure has a significant bearing on the consumer’s perception of quality and consistency of the brand, which is especially important for premium brands. Further, as spirits and Roll-on for wine producers expand into the fast-growing emerging markets, protection of product quality and brand integrity becomes increasingly important. Given the high excise duties charged in many emerging markets on the sale of imported alcohol, emerging markets are highly susceptible to counterfeiting of alcoholic beverages, especially premium brands. Safety closures, which provide significant anti-counterfeiting protection to spirits manufacturers, are therefore important packaging components for both producers and consumers, providing producers with an ability to protect their brand image and integrity and consumers with the confidence that they are purchasing an authentic branded item that has not been counterfeited. The global closure market, including Roll-on for wine and Spirits, is expected to grow at approximately 2% annually from 2021 to 2024, mainly driven by the Spirits “Safety and Luxury” segment with its increasing penetration as well as “Roll-on for wine screw caps” segment, almost in line with historical trends (3-5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024). As a result of the COVID-19 epidemic, the Closure global market decreased by 8% in 2020 (representing a four billion units drop) to reach 55 billion units. Preliminary indications for 2021 show that the market has almost entirely recovered since then. Guala is currently heavily focused on Roll-on for wine and spirits with sizeable presence across all key regions. Europe remains the largest market for Guala, representing 59% of its 2019 total net revenue by main geographical segment (i.e., based on the geographical location of the subsidiary of the Group that records the revenue rather than the location of the customer), followed by Americas and Asia regions which represent respectively 18% and 13% of 2019 net revenue.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Closure global market (Wine and Spirits), 2016-2024 (bn units)
Subsubsection Text: The Spirits’ closures market is Guala’s core market. In 2019, Guala’s addressable market accounted for more than 70% of the total spirits packaging market (or approximately 37 billion units out of approximately 52 billion units). This includes metal screw and cork closures. 122 ----- Guala focuses on using product range and relationships with longstanding customers to “upsell” from basic to more sophisticated closures, with increasing value add which leads to higher price realization. There is a strong market growth trend that is expected to continue to strengthen in the next few years with Safety and Luxury being the most attractive spirits segments, with an expected annual growth for the Safety segment close to 4% between 2021 and 2024 and 5% for Luxury segment in the same period. The Roll-on segment is expected to grow at a lower rate of 1% between 2021 and 2024. Despite having similar trends across countries, several peculiarities and/or differentiated scenarios should be considered, especially in terms of consumer habits, COVID-19 impact and closure type growth trends, which require a country-by-country analysis: - India: the overall market is expected to grow from approximately 8.3 billion units in 2021 to approximately 9.4 billion units in 2024 at a 4.2% CAGR over the same period. Safety closures are expected to grow from 4.5 to 5.3 billion units over the same period, with Guala holding approximately 50 to 60% market share, being the leader in such market). Safety closures are expected to continue gaining market share from Roll-on closures (which are expected to grow from 2.7 to 2.9 billion units between 2021 and 2024) achieving approximately 6% CAGR between 2021 and 2024. COVID-19 had a severe impact on the Indian market, mainly as a result of the restrictions adopted by the government (e.g., the 40-day ban), and a full rebound is expected in 2022. The macro-economic downturn is mostly impacting the Roll-on closure sector (consisting of approximately 2.8 billion units in 2019), which are typically used on cheaper “country liquor” bottles); it is expected that after the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic dissolve, demographic and social shift towards upper classes will continue, driving higher quality spirits consumption which would in turn positively increase demand for Safety closures (that are mainly applied to more expensive spirits). - Russia: the overall market is expected to decrease by a 0.1% CAGR between 2021 and 2024 with approximately 4.4 billion units expected to be sold between 2021 and 2024. The Roll-on segment is expected to be the most relevant category (with approximately 1.9 billion units in 2024), with Guala ranking second with an estimated market share of 10 to 20%). Roll-on closures are expected to lose market shares by 2024 to Safety (with approximately 1.5 billion units in 2024) and Luxury (with approximately 0.6 billion units in 2024), due to a trend towards premiumization. - United States: The Closure market is expected to grow at approximately 2% CAGR between 2021 and 2024, with approximately 1.7 and 1.8 billion units sold in 2021 and 2024, respectively. Roll-on closures and other closures represent the over 90% of total market); however, it is expected that Safety closures (in which Guala holds a market share of over 50%) will gain market share. - United Kingdom: The Roll-on market had approximately 62% market share in 2019. The overall closure market is expected to increase by 2.6% annually between 2021 and 2024 (from approximately 1.5 to approximately 1.6 billion units in 2021 and 2024, respectively), supported by a rebound in local consumption after decreasing by 11% in 2020 compared to the previous year. It is expected that in 2022 the market will recover to the 2019 pre-COVID-19 levels. - Poland and Ukraine: Poland is expected to grow at 0.5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024 (with approximately 0.9 and approximately 1.0 billion units sold in 2021 and 2024, respectively). The Polish market is focused on Roll-on closures (with approximately 75% market share), which trend is expected to continue. The Ukraine market is expected to decline by 0.5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024 (with approximately 0.6 billion units expected to be sold 2024), Luxury closures (representing approximately 25% market share) are expected to further grow supported by the trend of premiumization. Both the Polish and Ukraine markets are expected to recover to the 2019 pre-COVID-19 levels in 2022. - Mexico: The closure market (with approximately 0.6 billion units expected to be sold in 2024) is strictly tied to export dynamics (mainly of tequila). The market is fairly balanced between Roll-on and Safety closures (with Guala Closures holding approximately 60 to 70% market share in the Safety sector), with Safety closures expected to gain approximately 1% in 2024 compared to 2021, supported by the trend of premiumization. The overall closure market is expected to grow at 3% CAGR between 2021 and 2024. The Closure market is expected to recover to pre-COVID-19 level in 2021. 123 ----- India and the United States are driving most of the growth in the closure markets, driven by strong consumption dynamics. China’s growth is driven by increasing premiumization, which offsets substantially flat consumption levels. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The spirits market consists of brandy and cognac, liqueurs, rum, whisky, tequila and mezcal, white spirits (such as vodka) and other specialty spirits. Spirits closures typically have high client stickiness owing to their low incidence on final price/packaging cost making switching an unnecessary risk. At the same time, client relationship key drivers are proximity, caps performance and customisation (especially on Luxury) since closures are key to preserve organoleptic properties and to enhance branding. There are several types of closures for Spirits, categorised in four segments: (i) Roll-on, (ii) Safety, (iii) Luxury and (iv) Other. Guala’s core products focus on Roll-on, Safety and Luxury segments, which represent 71%, 23% and 6% of the Spirits markets, respectively. The Roll-on segment is mainly comprised of low price brands and more generally smaller bottle sizes. The main product from Guala is the Roll-on ROPP closure with basic tamper proofing, aluminium. This segment represents a true opportunity in terms of costs, as it is the lowest cost option-technology at scale. 121 ----- However, traceability is compromised with production and source information which can be easily counterfeited. The Safety segment consists of several offerings from more basic low-cost plastic systems to more complex combinations of advanced anti-refill and tamper-evident. The main product from Guala is the Anti-Refill insert (basic plastic insert) beneath with aluminium ROPP closure. This segment is mainly driven by guaranteed quality to consumer from both tamper and anti-refill, with product source traceable and verifiable. The Luxury segment includes a wide range of bespoke and Luxury closures. Guala offers a wide range of closures in this segment, from ROPP+ closures with additional basic Decoration added to one-off customized designs for highly premium products. This segment is driven by branding and customization, with high quality perception and unique propositions. However, the relative cost is lower as high cost per unit is applied but on higher priced bottles. Safety and Luxury segments have been out-performing the overall market with solid historical trend and strong outlook towards 2024. Guala is well positioned on both segments with a clear leadership on Safety (45-55% market share in 2019). There is sizeable growth available in East Europe due to further shift from grey spirits to official alcohol, as well as in India where solid future growth is forecasted, driven by ongoing premiumisation and safety focus. India is one of Guala’s most dominant markets, with 50-60% market share in 2019 in the Safety segment, and has a high forecasted annual growth of 5.8% from 2021 to 2024. Similarly, the United States is an important market for Guala, expected to grow at 4.4% annually from 2021 to 2024, where Guala is the market leader (holding 55-65% market share in 2019). Finally, the United Kingdom, with an expected 6.5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024) and Mexico, with an expected 3.3% CAGR between 2021 and 2024, are both countries where Guala Closures has a strong presence, with approximately 50% and 70% market share, respectively, in 2019. The Spirits closures market has grown at approximately 2% CAGR between 2016 and 2019, reaching approximately 18 billion caps in focus regions, which are India, Russia, USA, UK, Poland, Ukraine and Mexico. In such period, “Roll-on” closures remained almost flat with market share of approximately 42% share, unlike the “Safety” caps which reached 38% share growing faster at approximately 4% CAGR. Therefore, Safety closures are taking market share on Roll-on markets. The fastest growing segment has been “Luxury” with approximately 8% CAGR between 2016 and 2019, with a limited penetration (approximately 5%). The COVID-19 epidemic has severely impacted the closure industry, resulting in an approximately 9% decrease, with a strong rebound expected in 2021 and full recovery expected to be achieved between 2021 and 2022, depending on country by country dynamics. The post pandemic growth trends at approximately 2.5% annual growth between 2021 and 2024 are expected to be driven by positive outlook mainly in India, United States, United Kingdom and Mexico, with “Safety” and “Luxury” as top-growing segments. Subsubsection Title: Closure market per most relevant geographies (bn units)
Subsubsection Text: The screwcap market is very concentrated, with Guala, Amcor and Federfintech being the major global scale players. In particular, in 2019, Amcor and Federfintech held a market share of approximately 7 to 10% and 5 to 7%, respectively. Other main competitors have a global market share of approximately 20 to 30% whereas small local players represent approximately 25 to 35% of market share. Within such concentrated market, Guala Closures is the leader in the Roll-on for wine screwcaps market with approximately 25 to 126 ----- 35% market share in 2019. Guala is market leader in terms of market share in France, Australia, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Germany and Spain and the second biggest player in Italy and South Africa. Guala has a strong presence in the United States and Chile, being the third biggest player in both countries. Competition is also boosted by packaging generalists such as Orora and Nampak in certain markets as well as a few small local producers which offer basic products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Roll-on for wine closures market comprises traditional corks, synthetic corks and aluminium Roll-on for winecaps, with corks traditionally being the predominant type of Roll-on for wine closure. However, there has recently been increased adoption of aluminium Roll-on for winecaps, due to certain advantages, including improved preservation of the organoleptic properties of Roll-on for wine, consumer preference for ease of use and storage, and lower cost of packaging. Corks, which deteriorate over time, do not perform as well when travelling long distances over extended periods of time and often cause contamination of the Roll-on for wine. Moreover, Roll-on for winecaps are not susceptible to natural cork taint issues and therefore substantially reduce risk of spoiling. As a result, we have seen significant growth in the metal screw cap market in recent years as Roll-on for wine producers, wholesalers and retailers increasingly substitute metal for cork Roll-on for winecaps. We believe that metal screw caps today account for approximately 23% of all bottled Roll-on for wine worldwide and we believe that Guala is well positioned to capitalize on future growth in this industry. Screw cap market volumes depend on the adoption of bottled liquids and the adoption of screw caps. On the one hand, bottled volume drivers depend on domestic demand (with Roll-on for wine volumes driven by population and per capita consumption); production (with volumes produced by the national Roll-on for wineries impacting import share of consumption); volumes of imported and exported bulk and bottled Roll-on for wines; and size of packaging (with bottle formats changes impacting the number of closure compared to the actual volumes of Roll-on for wine being sold). On the other hand, the screw cap penetration depends on, among others, consumer acceptance (with consumer preference and habits being slow and difficult to change, with traditional European countries historically preferring cork over screwcaps); production landscape (fragmented Roll-on for wineries versus fewer concentrated large importer can favor the adoption of screw cap over corks); export share and consumer preferences of recipient countries (high exporting countries can based their decision on the adoption of screwcaps on the preferences of end consumers in the countries where the Roll-on for wine is dispatched); and retailer penetration (with retailer preferring screwcaps as there is less risk of return for tainted Roll-on for wine). Guala is the global leader in the screwcaps attractive market (with a market share of approximately 25 to 35% and approximately 7 billion of units sold in 2019 and 2020), growing at 3% CAGR between 2016 and 2019, due to evolving consumer habits, and the ability of screwcaps to preserve production quality while having a low incidence on the price and costs of packaging. Furthermore, the screwcap market has also demonstrated a higher resiliency to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the overall closure market, showing a strong rebound in 2021, further boosted by an approximately 3% CAGR growth expected between 2021 and 2024 and approximately 8 billion of units expected to be sold in 2024. The overall 32 billion units Roll-on for wine closures market showed a slow but steady growth between 2016 and 2019 of 1% CAGR, which is expected to continue over the next years, supported by stable consumption in “Roll-on for wine countries” due to the undergoing product innovation and a broader consumer base. Screwcaps overall market was supported by favorable trends such as practicality, sustainability, enhanced performance and reduced or stable cost, with the screwcap market representing approximately 23% of the overall closure market in 2019 and further growth expectation in the next years (as it is expected to increase at a slow but steady rate of up to approximately 24% in 2024. 125 ----- Europe, the United States, China and certain other geographic areas spread across the globe represent the most important Roll-on for wine regions for Guala: - Europe: representing approximately 54% of the overall market in 2019, the European market has grown at 2% CAGR between 2016 and 2019, and it is expected to recover to 2019 levels by 2021 after a 7% decline in 2020, and then to grow by 2% CAGR in 2021. Guala has a strong presence in the area, with a market share of approximately 25% in 2019, ranking first in most countries and facing low competition from a limited number of local players. After declining by 1% CAGR between 2010 and 2016, the Roll-on for wine market remains substantially flat until 2016-2019, supported new products (e.g., Roll-on for wine rosé) perceived as healthier and able to address a broader customer base (such as young generations, women). We expect this trend to continue post the COVID-19 pandemic. Within such market, growth is entirely driven by increasing screwcap penetration which shows a slow but steady trend in countries such as Spain, Italy and France, while it is reaching saturation in UK and Germany where screwcaps already represented approximately 50% of the overall market in 2019. - United States: the United States represent an attractive region (representing approximately 10% of screwcap market in 2021) and it is further expected to grow by approximately 5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024, driven by a positive trend in the Roll-on for wine market which is preferred over other beverages. Guala is the third biggest player in the U.S. market with a market share of approximately 10 to 20% in 2019. - China: while the screwcap market represented only approximately 5% of total market in 2019, it is expected to grow at approximately 10% CAGR between 2021 and 2024, mainly driven by increasing penetration of Roll-on for wine culture in the Chinese drinking habits and by a slight increase of use of screwcap closures in the market. - Other: among the geographies in which Guala Closures operate, four areas account for approximately 30% of the market: - Australia and New Zealand, which account for approximately 15% of market share, record a strong use of screwcap closures that saturated the market, with this trend been in line with the overall Roll-on for wine market which is expected to grow at approximately 2% between 2021 and 2024; - Chile and South Africa record a strong use of screwcap closures, resulting in approximately 4% expected growth between 2021 and 2024. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are the world’s leading producer of high value added closures for the spirits and wine industry. Through ongoing development and technological innovation, we believe that we are the top producer of non-refillable safety closures for the spirits industry with a market share by volume of units sold worldwide of more than 60%, the leading global producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures with a market share by volume of units sold of approximately 30%, and Europe’s largest producer of roll-on aluminum closures for wine, spirits and olive oil, in each case, in 2019. In aggregate, as of March 31, 2021, we operated from 30 production facilities, five research and development centers and three sales centers across 25 countries in five continents, and we produced and sold approximately 17 billion closures across than 300 models and in more than 100 countries in 2020. Our product lines include: Safety closures, Luxury closures, Roll-on closures and Roll-on for wine closures. We serve customers in several geographies and across four key end-markets: Spirits, Wine, Water and Beverages, and Oil and Condiments. The following charts illustrate the breakdown of our net revenue for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021 by product line, geography based on the geographical location of the subsidiary of the Group that records the revenue, and end-market.

Our position is further consolidated by our extensive IP portfolio, with, as of March 31, 2021, over 170 active patents and other IP rights related to the design and manufacture of closures, and continuous product innovation (over 35 new products have been launched over the last three years). We are the leading producer of safety closures by volume of units sold in a number of countries, including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. Notably, safety, closures are primarily used in emerging markets where there is a high risk of counterfeiting of alcohol. In addition, we are the leading manufacturer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures in Argentina, Australia, New Zealand, Poland (from where we serve the European market) and South Africa. We have a wide customer portfolio, which includes blue-chip major international and regional brands with whom we have built long-term relationships lasting more than 30 years in certain cases. We supply the top 10 premium spirits brands worldwide, including McDowell’s, Johnnie Walker, Bacardi, Jack Daniel’s and Absolut. The breadth and diversity of our customer base results in no single brand accounting for more than 3% of our net revenue during the last three years. Over the past decade, we have developed a strong focus on sustainability and ESG issues and strived to reduce the impact of our products and operations on the environment and climate change. We have made a long-term commitment to the design of sustainable solutions and continuously focus, together with selected partners, on the study, prototyping and development of closures made of materials with a low environmental impact over their life cycle, including recycled aluminum and recycled polymers as well as biopolymers and composite polymers. In 2020, recycled materials represented 27% of the raw materials used in our products. In November 2020, we launched a new range of sustainable products under the umbrella brand Blossom[™] and in December 2020, we signed an exclusivity agreement with Oceanworks[®], the largest global marketplace for sustainable materials, in order to develop a line of T-bar closures 128 ----- manufactured using fully recycled ocean-diverted plastic. We are committed to reducing the impact of our operations and wider value chain on the environment by reducing waste, increasing energy and water savings and using renewable energy, which is well-aligned with our focus on staying at the forefront of product innovation. We estimate that in 2020 we reduced our Scope 1 & 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions per ton of finished products by approximately 8% compared to 2016. With plants and offices in 25 countries and customers from over 100 countries, we also place great importance on diversity and inclusion as well as talent recruitment and management. As of March 31, 2021, the percentage of women holding leadership positions was 20.0% compared to 15.9% in 2018. In addition, following the appointment of the new board of directors on April 30, 2021, 44% of the members of our board of directors are women. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, we generated net revenue of €564.4 million, loss of €0.2 million, EBIT of €31.5 million, and Adjusted EBITDA of €98.2 million, resulting in an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 17.4%. We believe that our high margins are supported by our raw material cost management and our ability to manage raw material price fluctuations, global diversity and exposure to growth markets and ongoing management initiatives to improve production efficiencies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Market leader in safety closures for spirits and roll-on for wine closures
Subsubsection Text: According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, in 2019, the global spirits closures market reached approximately 51 billion of units sold, of which approximately 18 billion units in our key focus regions of India, Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom, Poland, Ukraine and Mexico, and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2.0% between 2021 and 2024, primarily driven by growth in the safety and luxury closures markets, especially in the United States and India. According to the same study, Guala’s global addressable Roll-on and Safety closures markets reached approximately 37 billion units in 2019 (compared to 33 billion in 2016). In addition, the global market for Roll-on for wine closures reached approximately 32 billion units in 2019 (compared to 30 billion units in 2016) and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2.0% between 2021 and 2024. We believe we are the market leader in the production of Safety closures for spirits with a market share by volume of units sold worldwide of more than 60%, and the leading producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures for the wine industry with a market share by volume of units sold of approximately 30%, in each case in 2019. We estimate that in 2019, our market shares for Safety and Roll-on for wine closures was six and four times greater than that of our nearest competitor, respectively. We also believe that we are a leading producer of aluminum closures for spirits in Europe. We believe that our leadership positions are sustainable due to our commitment to quality, research and development efforts, proprietary production technologies, long-standing customer relationships, excellent customer service and brand recognition. We are a renowned as a key partner in the spirits markets and sell our safety closures to some of the most prestigious multinational producers of spirits as well as a number of important regional producers in many of the countries in which we operate. For a spirits producer, packaging and brand are key elements in product identification and differentiation. Through technological innovation, we offer closures that enable our customers to better differentiate and position their brands against their competitors. We believe that the market for safety closures for spirits, including in emerging markets where premium brands are penetrating further, will continue to grow. See “Industry Overview”. Our safety closures help global manufacturers of spirits to protect against counterfeiting, particularly in emerging markets where the risk of counterfeiting is higher. As a result, we believe that we are the leading manufacturer of safety closures in various emerging countries, including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. Both global and local manufacturers of spirits also use safety and luxury closures to differentiate their brands. Our aluminum screwcaps for wine closures are designed to facilitate opening and closing the bottle and feature liners that keep the oxygenation of the wine in check so the wine retains its quality and flavour longer. In this market, we serve some of the major wine producers as well as a number of important regional players, such as Casella in New Zealand, Distell in South Africa and The Wine Group in the United States. We expect that the market for aluminum screwcaps for wine closures will continue to grow due to the advantages of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures over traditional cork closures. We believe that we are well placed to benefit from this growth because of our ability to cross-sell to manufacturers who also sell spirits, our capacity for decoration and design, the economies of scale permitted by our 129 ----- extensive distribution network and the proximity of several of our plants to “New World” wine producers in Australia, New Zealand, South America and South Africa.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Long-standing and trusted blue chip customer relationships, high switching costs and diverse customer base
Subsubsection Text: Our consistent product quality and customer service have allowed us to develop strong and longstanding relationships with our customers, both in mature and emerging markets. We enhance customer loyalty through our research and development activities, which are often driven by the specific business requirements of our customers. We have strong and long-standing relationships with most of the large global producers of spirits, including Bacardi, Brown Forman, Campari, Diageo and Pernod Ricard, and we work closely with individual brands owned by these producers. We also serve major wine producers, such as Accolade, Castel, Caviro and Torres, Concha y Toro, Constellations Brands, Pernod Ricard and Treasury wines. In addition, we serve a broad range of regional and local producers of spirits and wines across all of our geographies. In 2020, approximately 30% and 70% of our net revenues was generated 130 ----- from sales of products to global and regional spirits producers, respectively. We have long-term relationships with many of our customers, which in some cases exceed 30 years. Due to the nature of bottle closures, we work in close partnership with leading spirits and wines producers in the study, prototyping and development of highly innovative closures specifically designed for their end-products, particularly safety and luxury closures, which often become integral parts of the overall packaging design featured in their advertising campaigns. For example, we have developed the “Neptune” closure for the SKYY Vodka brand, the “Florence” closure for Pernod Ricard’s Ballantine’s in both open pourer and non-refillable versions and the luxury quality “Ultis” closure for Pernod Ricard’s Chivas Whiskey. In recent years, the trend for customized solutions has resulted in the increase of the share of products that we co-design and co-develop with our customers, particularly for luxury closures. For example, we currently co-develop all of the luxury closures with premium spirit brands including, among others, Macallan, William Grant’s, Haig Club, Dewar’s. The trend for customized solutions has also driven the co-development of highly customized Safety closures with brands such as Jose Cuervo, Khortitsa and Russian Standard. At the same time, we continue to develop products that can be sold to all customers in specific end-markets, particularly in the wine and water closures market. The high degree integration of our closures with customers’ end-products and the fact that our closures are covered by patents or other forms of intellectual property protection, makes it more difficult and costly for our customers to source alternative closures from our competitors. In addition, our longstanding, collaborative relationships with leading brands and our ability to leverage our global platform to serve their needs across multiple geographies have allowed our closures to be used in our customers’ products globally, often becoming industry standard. In safety closures, we are typically the sole supplier for a particular brand in a particular region. At the same time, our customer base is largely diversified and, while certain of our customers own multiple brands, no single brand accounted for more than 3% of our net revenue in 2019 and 2020. As a result of the time and resources invested in joint product development activities with customers, we also often receive recognition. For example, the e-closures equipped with NeˇSTGATE[™] NFC technology that we launched in 2020 with Vigneti Massa, a well-established winemaker located in Piedmont, Italy, received three prestigious awards in 2019: the Alufoil Trophy, the SIMEI Innovation Challenge and the WorldStar Award. In addition, in February 2020 we received, together with Vigneti Massa, a special prize for innovation in the wine sector at the inaugural Food & Wine Italia Awards. We believe that the multinational scope of our operations and our ability to meet our customers’ quality standards across geographic markets are increasingly important factors to our large global customers. In addition, our international presence allows us to operate in close physical proximity to our customers’ production facilities and meet their product and design requirements with greater flexibility and at a more competitive price and quality than our competitors.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Highly differentiated proprietary engineered product portfolio supported by a strong focus on research and development
Subsubsection Text: We believe that a key reason for our strong positioning in the global markets is the wide range of products in our portfolio, which we sell to customers operating in four key end-markets: spirits, wine, water and beverages, and olive oil and condiments. Our safety closures, which are highly engineered packaging components generally consist of two to 12 different components, range from tamper-evident seals to more sophisticated non-refillable devices covering the medium to high value added range of the closures market. Our luxury closures, typically designed for high-end spirits produced in limited quantities, are made of both aluminum and plastic, are customized according to the requirements of our customers and can include ribbons, seals and unusual shapes. Our roll-on closures and other product lines provide a range of products for spirits and mineral water and often provides an entry point for up-selling customers to other higher value added product lines. Our roll-on for wine closures are made from aluminum and customers can choose whether or not to include a tamper-evident band for protection against counterfeiting. In line with our long-term commitment to design sustainable solutions and increasing customer focus on sustainability in their own products, we recently developed and launched several sustainable solutions, such as products of our Blossom[™] line, including Greencap[®], a fully removable and disposable aluminum screwcap made of recycled materials, a luxury T-bar closure fully made of recycled ocean-diverted plastic and agglomerated cork that we developed in collaboration with Oceanworks[®], the largest global marketplace for sustainable materials, and Spring Blossom, a new aluminum closure for water with a tamper-evident ring produced from completely bio-based polymers. 131 ----- Our research and development capabilities and our customer service functions enable us to continuously improve and expand our product offering, including in response to customer feedback, and the solutions we develop are often proprietary in nature and covered by patents, trade secrets and know-how, all of which ensures our product portfolio remains differentiated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Focus on innovation, technology and product development
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to product research and development and the digitalization of packaging, and we believe that we are a leading innovator in the closures industry, with a record of developing new and enhanced products with improved functionality, reliability and sustainability. In addition, the increased interconnectivity of our closures leads to closer integration between packaging suppliers and customers during the designing, ordering and delivering phases as closures are closely tailored to customers’ needs. We focus on the study, prototyping and development of highly engineered innovative solutions together with selected partners, particularly for safety closures, and we protect our know-how by applying for patents and other intellectual property protections for our products and processes. As of March 31, 2021, we held, or had lodged applications for, more than 170 patents, including 113 active patent families, 10 utility model families, 5 combined patents and utility model families and 44 protected industrial designs. Patents covered approximately 29% of our net revenue in the year ended December 31, 2020. The proprietary nature of our products makes it more challenging for new market entrants to effectively compete with us, as our research and development capabilities allow us to strengthen our relationships with customers. We operate five research and development centers in Italy, Scotland, Mexico, Ukraine and Luxembourg. We believe that our developments allow us to derive a significant competitive advantage in our markets because more advanced products generally provide us with higher margins. During the last three years, we have launched over 35 new products. Examples of some of our most recent innovations include various e-closures with fully integrated NFC capabilities, including our new series of e-closures under the NeˇSTGATE[™] brand, which we started to develop in 2018, including the first wine bottles equipped with NFC technology in Europe, which we launched in partnership with Vigneti Massa in 2020, and e-closures specifically designed for Irish whiskey Jameson, which we launched in 2020. The NFC technology is revolutionizing conventional bottle packaging by integrating connectivity features into bottle closures for spirits, wine, olive oil and beverages. In particular, our NeˇSTGATE[™] e-closures are equipped with a special microchip inside the capsule that is readable by all compatible smartphones, without downloading any specific application, providing consumers with the certification of authenticity and unlocking all information about the product, directly linking them to the brand and boosting customer engagement and loyalty. Our NeˇSTGATE[™] product range also comprises various QR code-based as well as more basic serial number-based models for wine and beverages. Most recently, we designed an electronic tamper-evident closure equipped with proximity sensors capable of detecting nearby objects in partnership with NXP Semiconductors, which we plan to launch in the coming months. Following our recent acquisition of a minority stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in London, we are able to offer our customers turnkey solutions, including digital platforms, integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions. We also have developed proprietary manufacturing processes that help reduce our operating costs and improve our profitability. In certain cases, we work with our customers to develop new and more competitive products. By offering support and by providing the technical expertise and service needed to develop new products, we have enhanced our relationships with our customers. In addition, in order to refresh our current product portfolio and meet the increasing demand for customized products, our research and development team is currently developing a new series of products tailored for individual brands and equipped with innovative technological and sustainable features and with a sophisticated design, which we expect to launch between 2021 and 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Proven track record of successful acquisitions focused on creating long-term value
Subsubsection Text: Over the past two decades, our growth has been complemented through strategically identified acquisitions and other business combinations and investments, which enabled us to strengthen our market position and further increase our market share. In doing so, we have increased the number of geographical markets in which we operate, including Australia, Bulgaria, France, Poland, South Africa, Ukraine, Belarus, Germany and Turkey and have expanded our presence in new segments and the types of products which we offer, including aluminum screwcaps for wine closures. More recently, in 2018, we acquired United Closures and Plastics (now called Guala Closures UCP), a Scottish company with a long-standing 132 ----- presence in the Scottish market, which supplies some landmark scotch whisky brands. In 2020, we acquired Closurelogic GmbH, a German manufacturer specializing in aluminum closures mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral water sector, as well as its Turkish subsidiary. In the same year, we acquired a minority stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in London focusing on integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions, which we increased from 20% to 30% in the first quarter of 2021. We believe that we have been successful at identifying and integrating acquired companies within the Group and at delivering synergies. Our success in identifying and integrating acquired companies has contributed to the diversification of our geographic and product category profile and the maintenance of attractive margins.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Best-in-class financial profile with proven resilience, with a decade of strong Adjusted EBITDA margins despite foreign exchange rate and raw materials price fluctuations
Subsubsection Text: We manage our business with a focus on achieving and maintaining a strong Adjusted EBITDA margin as compared to those of our industry peers. We have a strong track-record of more than a decade of revenue growth and stability of Adjusted EBITDA margins within a very narrow and consistent range. We believe our business is resilient against the impact of adverse foreign exchange movements and raw materials price fluctuations. Furthermore, we believe that the diversified nature of our end-markets and customer base, coupled with our global presence have allowed us to maintain strong performance in 2020 despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, our Adjusted EBITDA margins are supported by hedging arrangements covering a portion of our costs for raw materials via forward contracts. From time to time, our Adjusted EBITDA margins are impacted by the initial dilutive effect of strategic acquisitions; however, we strive to support our acquired businesses in order to maintain high group-wide margins as we strive to achieve industry leading profitability. As a result, we believe our average Adjusted EBITDA margin from 2015 to 2020 (including pre-merger Guala) was one of the three highest among our direct competitors within the industry. Our profit/(loss) for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, represented 2.4%, (1.0)% and (0.0%), respectively, of our net revenue. We have achieved strong Adjusted EBITDA margins of 18.7%, 17.1% and 17.4% in the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, and in the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, respectively. We were able to achieve these results leveraging both organic and inorganic growth, in spite of the fluctuations in exchange rates and raw material prices and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Following the economic recovery starting in the third and fourth quarter of 2020, our sales volumes returned to pre-pandemic levels. As a result, while our net revenue in 2020 decreased by €34.5 million, or 5.7%, to €572.0 million from €606.5 million in 2019, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in 2020 decreased by only €2.7 million, or 0.4%, to €603.8 million from €606.5 million in 2019. In the first quarter of 2021, our overall sales volumes continued to improve despite the loss of volumes from sales in the European water and beverage market, which was negatively impacted by the restrictions implemented in the HORECA industries due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, while net revenue decreased by €7.6 million, or 5.2%, from €145.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €138.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the first quarter of 2021 increased by €1.3 million, or 0.9%, from €145.9 million in the first quarter of 2020 to €147.2 million. Our resilient industry leading margins coupled disciplined approach to working capital and capital expenditure led to a strong Adjusted cash conversion ratio of 88% in each of the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020. The above information should be read in conjunction with the information contained in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Strong focus on ESG and sustainability by pursuing ambitious targets
Subsubsection Text: Over the past decade, we have developed a strong focus on sustainability and ESG issues and strived to reduce the impact of our products and operations on the environment and climate change. Going forward, we intend to continue to focus on sustainability and ESG and have developed a comprehensive strategy to optimize sustainability across our operations and identified a series of sustainability targets. We have made a long-term commitment to the design of sustainable solutions and have been, together with selected partners, studying, prototyping and developing closures made of materials with a low environmental impact over their life cycle, including recycled aluminum and recycled polymers as well as biopolymers and composite polymers. In 2020, recycled materials represented 27% of the raw materials used in our products and we intend to increase this percentage to 35% by the end of 2025. Our product portfolio already comprises several sustainable products under the 133 ----- umbrella brand Blossom[™], including Greencap[®], a fully removable and disposable aluminum screwcap made of recycled materials, a luxury T-bar closure fully made of recycled ocean-diverted plastic and Spring Blossom, a new aluminum closure for water with a tamper-evident ring produced from completely bio-based polymers. In line with our long-term commitment on sustainability, we intend to increase the share of environmentally-friendly solutions in our portfolio, by extending our existing range of sustainable closures and developing new solutions. In order to protect the environment, meet sustainability needs and contribute to the mitigation of the effects of climate change, we focus on minimizing environmental pollution, reducing waste, increasing energy and water savings and using renewable energy. We estimate that in 2020 we reduced our Scope 1 & 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions per ton of finished products by approximately 8% compared to 2016, and we intend to decrease such emissions further by optimizing processes and optimizing loads and logistics across our supply chain. In addition, in the first quarter of 2021, we implemented “Iris”, a new software developed entirely in-house, at our Spinetta Marengo facility in Italy, which is able to connect 150 pieces of machinery simultaneously, perform data analysis and make recommendations to the facility’s operator in line with our key sustainability principles. Going forward, we plan to implement Iris at all our facilities worldwide.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Experienced and committed management team supported by clear and simple reporting lines and a decentralized sales structure
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from the experience of our key management who each have decades of experience in the closures and packaging industry. In addition, in 2021 we welcomed our new Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Gabriele del Torchio, who brings a wealth of experience in running high profile businesses and a track record of approximately 45 years in managing industrial companies. Management has consistently demonstrated its ability to develop our business by anticipating market trends and dynamics, creating significant added value for customers and entering new geographies and product markets, underpinned by clear and simple reporting lines directly to the Chief Operating Officer, who is supported by two regional managers for the Americas and the Asia Pacific region, and by decentralized local sale structure with a strong network of area managers responsible for day-to-day relationships with local customers. Our effective management structure has also allowed us to take swift action in response to the weak global economic environment in past years, including headcount reductions, temporary plant shutdowns and exits from non-core markets, and in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In recent years, management has continued to implement cost reduction measures and to improve cash flow management while pursuing our strategy to enter new geographies and product markets through organic growth and by acquiring and successfully integrating companies already operating in our industry.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

We believe our proximity to our customers enhances our ability to respond quickly to changing local trends. In addition, our global scale enables us to source capacity from different locations based on supply and demand levels so that we can serve our customers across multiple geographies depending on their needs and requirements. As a result, we are able to develop new products and value added solutions that meet the requirements of customers in our key end-markets while limiting our labor costs and creating production synergies, all of which positions us well for future growth. Our global platform of technologically advanced facilities is equipped with state-of-the-art technologies, processing solutions, quality controls and machinery. Over the years, we have developed proprietary production technologies that are crucial for the manufacture of technologically advanced closures. As part of our efforts to make our manufacturing process more efficient by leveraging on technological innovations, we regularly pilot and implement various projects across our manufacturing facilities, including a multi-injection project in our facility in Colombia to develop closures made of different plastics in the same mould in order to eliminate the assembly stage of our production process and provide significant additional anti-counterfeiting protection to our closures. In addition, we focus on widescale flexible automation of our productions processes, which we plan to implement also for small and medium-sized product batches. As customers increasingly demand more product customization, we believe that our technologically advanced facilities position us to adapt to this market trend and meet the increasingly complex specifications of our customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Continue to invest in product development and digitalization and cross-sell or up-sell high end products to existing customers
Subsubsection Text: Competition in our key market segments is focused mainly on product quality, innovation, digitalization, sustainability and customer service. As a result, we believe that developing reliable products with innovative functional features, aesthetic appeal and other improvements are necessary for enhancing demand for our products. We plan to continue improving our product offering technologically and innovatively by developing new ranges of safety closures that offer varying degrees of protection against counterfeiting while promoting our customers’ brand images worldwide. In particular, we plan to continue to focus on the digitalization of our closures by offering more products equipped with innovative technological features, such as NFC microchips and QR code-based solutions. We will continue to work closely with our customers to develop new and more innovative solutions and we believe that the increasing digitalization of closures will lead to even closer integration with our customers’ end-products and will position us for further growth. In addition, we intend to develop new aesthetically appealing styles to complement existing products and meet the growing marketing requirements of our customers. We also intend to encourage customers of our roll-on closures to upgrade and convert to more sophisticated, aesthetic, luxurious and protective safety closures where appropriate. In order to refresh our current 134 ----- product portfolio and meet the increasing demand for customized products, our research and development team is currently developing a new series of products tailored for individual brands and equipped with innovative technological and sustainable solutions and with a sophisticated design, which we expect to launch between 2021 and 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Increase sales of premium products through a focus on safety and luxury closures across different geographies
Subsubsection Text: In recent years, we have expanded our global presence and we believe we are the leading producer of safety closures by volume in several emerging markets, including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. In 2019, we started our operations in Africa following the inauguration of Guala Closures East Africa’s new facility in Kenya and opened a new facility in Belarus. In 2020, we entered the Turkish market following our acquisition of Closurelogic GmbH and its assets in Turkey. We intend to continue our geographical expansion by consolidating our presence in these and other markets, with a particular focus on specialty closures for the spirits market, including added-value safety and luxury closures. According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, the global spirits closures market has grown at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2% between 2016 and 2019, reaching approximately 37 billion closures in 2019, of which approximately 18 billion units in our key focus regions of India, Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom, Poland, Ukraine and Mexico. According to this study, the market for safety closures represented approximately 38% of the global spirits closures market in 2019, while 42% was represented by roll-on closures. Despite the negative impact from the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in a 9% decrease in the size of the spirits closures market in our key focus regions in 2020, a strong rebound is expected in 2021, with a full recovery predicted to occur between 2021 and 2022, on a country-by-country basis. In particular, it is expected that the global spirits closures market will grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2.5% between 2021 and 2024, mainly driven by growth in the safety and luxury closures markets, which are expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 4% and 5%, respectively, between 2021 and 2024. We expect significant growth for the specialty closures segments in emerging markets. In recent years, these markets have experienced an increase in the consumption of branded spirits. We believe this has resulted in a greater demand for sophisticated anti-counterfeiting systems (such as our non-refillable safety closures) by the producers of such spirits and we expect such demand to continue to grow. In addition, producers are increasingly using safety closures as a marketing tool to create a premium brand image through the use of exclusive packaging. We believe that our leading position means that we are well placed to benefit from the expected future growth in the safety closures market worldwide, including in emerging markets. We aim to take advantage of this trend by sustaining or increasing our presence in these markets. We intend to achieve this by strengthening our relationships with drinks producers and consolidating our presence and infrastructure in the relevant countries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Position the Group to benefit from expected growth in the market for wine closures and bottled water
Subsubsection Text: According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, the aluminum screwcaps for wine closures market grew at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 3% between 2016 and 2019, as a result of evolving consumer habits and the ability of screwcaps to preserve product quality while having a low incidence on the price and costs of packaging. The screwcap market has also demonstrated a higher resiliency to the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the overall closures market, showing a strong rebound in 2021 to date, which we expect will continue, and an expected growth at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 3% between 2021 and 2024. We believe that aluminum winecaps today account for approximately 23% of all bottled wine worldwide and we believe that we are well positioned to capitalize on future growth in this industry, especially as large regions such as North America and Europe move towards greater usage of aluminum winecaps. We believe we are one of the top producers of aluminum winecap closures, with a market share by volume of units sold in 2019 of approximately 30%. We expect growth in the wine closures market to continue due to increasing end-consumer preference for aluminum closures rather than cork. We believe that our leading position in this market means we are well placed to benefit from this growth. We aim to take advantage of this trend by sustaining or increasing our presence this end-market, by strengthening our relationships with wine producers, particularly those which are also active in the spirits market, by developing new and aesthetically attractive closures, including closures with safety elements and innovative features, and by consolidating our operations in the countries and regions where wine closures are purchased in large volumes. 135 ----- According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, the market for closures for bottled water, measured by closures unit, grew at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 5% between 2015 and 2019, and is expected to grow further a compound annual growth rate of approximately 6% between 2021 and 2024, mainly driven by growth in population and increased shift towards healthier beverages. In particular, the premium market for glass water bottles is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 7% over the same timeframe. We believe we are currently recognized as a key closure producer in the premium market for glass water bottles, particularly following our acquisition of Closurelogic, a German manufacturer specializing in aluminum closures mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral water sector, in 2020. Going forward, we intend to take advantage of these strong growth trends in the glass-bottle closures market by leveraging our core business technology in metal screw caps for spirit closures as well as our expertise in tamper-evident systems.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Carry out further selected acquisitions in core and adjacent markets
Subsubsection Text: During the last 10 years, we have grown both organically and through strategically identified acquisitions. In doing so we have increased the number of geographical markets in which we operate (for example, we established our presence in Australia, Bulgaria, France, Poland, South Africa, Ukraine, Belarus, Germany and Turkey) and expanded our presence in new segments and the types of products which we offer. Most recently, in 2018, we acquired Guala Closures UCP, a Scottish company with a long-standing presence in the Scottish market, and in 2020, we acquired Closurelogic GmbH, a German manufacturer specialising in aluminum closures mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral water sector, as well as its Turkish subsidiary. In the same year, we also acquired a minority stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in London focusing on integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions. In the first quarter of 2021, we increased our stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd. from 20% to 30%. We believe that we have been successful at identifying and integrating acquired companies and at exploiting the synergies offered by such acquisitions. Going forward, we intend to continue to identify appropriate expansion opportunities where we consider it would help us grow in new geographical markets with high levels of alcohol consumption that we view as underpenetrated including, for example, South Africa and certain countries in Asia. In addition, we intend to continue to identify appropriate acquisitions and other development opportunities that would allow us to consolidate our position in the market for aluminum and plastics closures, and diversify our business through the expansion in the market for closures made of alternative materials such as cork as well as in adjacent product markets, such as food and beverages, including water, beauty and the pharmaceutical industries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Further improve operational efficiency by optimizing manufacturing and the supply chain
Subsubsection Text: The optimization and automation of our manufacturing processes and the investment in new equipment for our technologically advanced plants is one of our core areas of focus and going forward we expect to continue to invest in innovative technologies for supply chain management in order to optimize our production and supply chain network efficiency. To further improve the efficiency of our production processes, we aim to (i) modernize and automate our production processes on a wide-scale through our flexible automation project, including for small and medium-sized product batches, which we believe will enable us to respond promptly to evolving market needs; (ii) continue to advance our production processes by implementing systems to monitor and improve our entire production cycles (the “continuous improvement” program) and our multi-injection project aimed at eliminating the assembly stage of the manufacturing process; and (iii) hedge part of the risks of price fluctuation in the purchase price of aluminum through forward purchases on the London Metal Exchange through the use of hedging depending on the commodity price environment. We endeavor to leverage key focus platforms across the Group and improve profitability of selected sites opportunistically.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Continue prudent financial management, focusing on liquidity, deleveraging, Net Working Capital and hedging of raw materials
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the Group has benefited from prudent financial management throughout its history, with a particular focus on cost reduction and cash flow management. We intend to use our cash flow generation capacity, and our Revolving Credit Facility, to maintain appropriate levels of liquidity and Net Working Capital in order to enable us to respond to unexpected changes in economic conditions. We will continue to monitor our capital expenditures carefully in order to benefit from favorable economic 136 ----- conditions and be able to take advantage of opportunities for acquisitions, and to continue to implement the Group’s strategy, particularly in emerging markets. We will also continue to carefully monitor fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, both aluminum and plastics, and changes in prevailing currency exchange rates. We intend to manage raw material price fluctuations by hedging our exposures where appropriate as well as currency fluctuations by matching revenue to expenditure in each currency where possible.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We commenced operations in 1954 as a manufacturer of plastic closures for spirits. Early in our development we adopted an international focus, initially by licensing our products to local producers and later by establishing a direct presence in the markets we targeted. Over the last two decades, we have expanded our product lines and geographic markets through both organic growth and acquisitions. Prior to the 2018 Business Combination, our expansion has included the commencement in 2015 of production operations in Chile, the acquisition in 2016 of 70% of CapMetal SAS in France (since renamed Guala Closures France SAS), a company specialized in the production of aluminum screwcaps, and the acquisitions in 2017 of Axiom, a leading Indian company active in the production of safety closures for spirits, of the activities of Limat S.A. de C.V., a Mexican company specialized in the manufacturing of wood overcaps for top-range spirit bottles, and of the screw cap activities of Industria Corchera S.A. (“ICSA”) in Chile. On July 31, 2018, pre-merger Guala, was acquired by Space4, a special purpose acquisition company and it merged by incorporation into Space4 on August 6, 2018 with the resulting entity concurrently adopting Guala’s corporate name, Guala Closures S.p.A., and transferring its registered office to Guala’s registered office, Via Rana 12, 15122, Alessandria, Spinetta Marengo, Italy. On the same date, our ordinary shares and Market Warrants were admitted to and started trading on the Star segment of the Italian Stock Exchange (Mercato Telematico Azioniario) and in September 2019, we were admitted to the FTSE Italy Mid Cap index. Following our admission to trading on the Italian Stock Exchange, we continued the expansion of our product lines and geographic reach. In 2018, we acquired Guala Closures UCP, a Scottish company with a long-standing presence in the Scottish market, which supplies closures to some landmark scotch whisky brands. In 2019, we started our operations in Africa following the inauguration of Guala Closures East Africa’s new facility in Kenya and opened a new facility in Belarus. In 2020, we acquired Closurelogic GmbH, a German manufacturer specializing in aluminum closures mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral water sector, as well as its Turkish subsidiary. In 2020, we also acquired a minority stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in London focusing on integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions, such as closures equipped with NFC capabilities. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have historically divided our operations into two divisions: Closures and PET. The Closures division represents our core business and produces a wide range of closures for diversified end-markets. The PET division mainly produces standard and custom moulds, PET bottle and miniatures. Our Closures division represents our core business, which is specialized in the following product lines: Safety closures, Luxury closures, Roll-on closures and Roll-on for wine closures. Safety and Luxury closures are specialty closures. In 2019, we reorganized our business structure to focus on our Closures division. We sold part of the Spanish assets of our PET division to third parties and transferred the remaining PET assets from Spain to the United Kingdom. As a result, we no longer consider the PET division a core business. The PET division is now closely connected to the Closures division as customers in the spirit sector are the same and because the PET division’s activities are substantially an accessory market related to the sale of closures to our customers. As a result of this reorganization, sales generated in our Closures division and from sales of PET products accounted for 99.5% and 0.5% of our net revenue, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. In 2019, following the partial divestment of our PET division and the sale of GCL Pharma S.r.l., which operated our pharma product line, we changed the presentation of our segmentation by product. In particular, we no longer consider it a core business of the Group and no longer report our PET revenues separately. For reporting purposes, we include revenues from sales of products manufactured by our PET division, together with residual revenues not in included in any of the other product lines, under the residual category “Other”.
