Subsubsection Text: _Safety closures_ We produce safety closures almost exclusively for spirits, wine and vegetable oil products, which are fitted with special devices to limit counterfeiting of the end-product, such as non-refillable devices. We are the world’s leading producer of safety closures for spirits, with a market share by volume of units sold worldwide in 2019 of more than 60%. Safety closures are primarily made of plastics and have a complex structure that generally consist of two to 12 different components. Our safety closures are designed to prevent our competitors from imitating our closures and their unique components. The features of our safety closures products can include tamper-evident seals, non-refillable valve systems, positive lock systems and aluminum cladding. Safety closures are primarily used by our customers when selling their products in emerging markets, where the risk of counterfeiting is higher. We have been active in the production of safety closures since the 1970s when we launched the famous 1031 model safety closure. Most of our older patents related to the creation of innovative solutions for tamper-evident and tamper proofing features in closures with these features being implemented alongside new designs of plastic components and the interaction of plastic components with aluminum shells. Our more recent patent applications take advantage of new technologies, in an innovative manner and for the first time in the closures field, include production cost savings and sustainable methods (for waste reduction) as well as improvements in the efficiency of tamper-evident and anti-counterfeiting measures. 138 ----- Safety closures are increasingly being used as a marketing tool to create a premium brand image through exclusive packaging. In response to the needs of our customers who wish to distinguish their brands, we also design and produce safety customized closures according to their specifications. For the year ended December 31, 2020 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, our Safety closures product line generated net revenue of €203.8 million and €202.2 million, representing 35.6% and 35.8%, respectively, of our net revenue for the relevant period. _Luxury closures_ Our luxury closures product line specializes in the production of customized plastic, wood and aluminum closures, typically designed for high-end spirits that are produced in limited quantities. We focus on aesthetic appeal and design and use advanced decoration techniques, including 3D embossing and metal sputtering, to customize closures. These closures are designed to give a more distinctive character to our customers’ brands and to improve the aesthetic appeal of their end-products. Luxury closures can be designed to suit different brand and market requirements. Our leadership in the Safety and Roll-on closures segments facilitated our penetration in the Luxury closures market, particularly because often the customers of these closures are the same and we have been able to leverage our long-standing relationships with their procurement, technical and marketing representatives for Safety and Roll-on closures, who are typically also responsible of Luxury closures. Our luxury closures collection includes: - Gravitas, closures made of a new patented material that brings together the versatility of plastic and luxury feel of metal material; - Essence, customized closures made of high quality natural wood; - Icon, closures which feature a combination of materials and technologies that gives closures a touchable appearance; - Torq, closures which combine the retention properties of a screw thread with the premium feel of a cork; and - Opéra, closures made of eccentric materials with a noble and contemporary touch. We believe that we are the largest producer of standard aluminum closures in Europe. Our roll-on closures also include closures for bottles of soft drinks and beer. Our Roll-on closures portfolio ranges from the simplest screwcaps to more customized solutions decorated with advanced techniques, such as lithography, hot-foil, relief or bas-relief punching. Roll-on closures are primarily made out of aluminum and can typically comprise up to four different components. Our products comprise (i) long and short aluminum closures fitted with a thread enabling them to be screwed directly onto the neck of the bottle and (ii) aluminum closures with plastic components enabling special functions, such as anti-drop spouts (mainly designed for olive oil bottles) or flow inhibitors (mainly designed for vinegar bottles). We seek to, where appropriate, migrate customers from Roll-on closures to higher margin Safety closures through a process of customer education and product innovation. 141 ----- The table below sets out certain information for the principal closures in our Roll-on closures product line.

For the year ended December 31, 2020 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, our Roll-on closures product line generated net revenue of €201.0 million and €196.4 million, representing 35.1% and 34.8%, respectively, of our net revenue for the relevant period. _Roll-on for wine closures_ Aluminum screwcap closures specifically dedicated to the wine sector are easy to open and convenient to store as well as lower cost than traditional cork closures. Screwcap closures for wine offer further advantage to natural and synthetic corks for bottled wine as screwcaps are not susceptible to natural cork taint issues and, therefore, do not create a risk of spoiling the wine contained in the bottle. Demand for aluminum screwcaps closures for wine has increased in recent years, and in 2020 aluminum screwcap closures were used on approximately 23% of all bottled wine worldwide. Flat coated and printed aluminum sheets are pressed to produce the closure shell, which is then finished to meet the customer’s needs through the use of printing machines. Our Roll-on wine closures product line includes a range of product and technological features, including decoration, concealed threading, tamper-evident band, pressure retention and varying levels of permeability including by use of controlled OTR liners. Our key Roll-on for wine closures include the Liners by Oneoseal[®], which we started developing together with Manufacture Generale de Joints in 2015, including: - Onyx, liners equipped with an aluminum layer to ensure maximum impermeability to oxygen; - Ivory, liners that enable the amount of free sulfur dioxide (SO2) to be reduced when bottling; and - Coral, liners that reduce evaporation of wines with high tannin. The market for aluminum screwcaps for wine closures continues to grow strongly as a result of the superior performance of aluminum closures compared to traditional cork closures. The market growth has been driven by wine producers in New Zealand, Australia, Chile, Argentina and South Africa, which preferred aluminum screwcaps over cork ones for various reasons, including practicality of use and cost benefits, and is expected to be driven in the future by greater use of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures in Europe, the U.S. and Latin America, where we perceive significant potential for further growth. During the years, we expanded our presence in the wine closures market through a series of acquisitions, including Global Cap in 2003, Auscap in Australia in 2007, 70% of DGS in Poland in 2011, MCG in South Africa in 2012 and 70% of CapMetal SAS (since renamed Guala Closures France SAS) in France in 2016. In 2015, we commenced production operations in Chile, bolstered with our acquisition in 2017 of the screw cap activities of ICSA in Chile. More recently, in February 2020, we expanded our production of wine closures in Europe through the acquisition of Closurelogic GmbH, a German manufacturer specialising in aluminum closures mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral water. We believe that we are the leading producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures, with approximately 30% market share by volume of units sold in 2019. 142 ----- The table below sets out certain information for the principal closures in our Roll-on for wine product line.

Subsubsection Text: (1) Consists of a broad range of end-markets, including the pharmaceutical market for PET products. _Spirits_ We are a renowned key partner in the spirits markets. Through technological innovation, we offer spirits makers solutions that increasingly prevent counterfeiting while meeting their needs for premiumization and differentiation. 143 ----- In the spirits end-market, we primarily sell safety, luxury and roll-on aluminum closures to some of the most prestigious multinational producers of spirits (such as Bacardi, Brown Forman, Campari, Diageo and Pernod Ricard). We also sell our products to a number of important regional producers in many of the countries in which we operate (such as state distilleries in Colombia, large whisky producers in India, and vodka producers in Russia). In the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, net revenue generated in the spirits end-market represented 61.0% of our net revenue for the period. _Wine_ With screw-on aluminum closures, wine is more stable over time and its balance is not compromised during transport. Our caps are designed to facilitate opening and closing the bottle and feature liners that limit the oxygenation of the wine so the wine retains its quality and flavour for a longer period of time. In the wine end-market, we primarily sell roll-on aluminum closures to wine producers. The principal customers of our wine closures are major wine producers (such as Accolade, Castel, Caviro and Torres, Concha y Toro, Constellations Brands, Pernod Ricard and Treasury wines) as well as a number of important regional players (such as Casella in New Zealand, Distell in South Africa and The Wine Group in the United States). In the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, net revenue generated in the wine end-market represented 20.8% of our net revenue for the period. _Water and beverages_ We produce aluminum closures for carbonated and still beverages in glass bottles, fruit juice and non-alcoholic beverages. We supply some of the top international brands with generic closures or tamperevident closures that feature capsules based on a patented system to show when a bottle has been opened. In the water and beverages end-market, we primarily sell roll-on aluminum closures to producers of mineral water, such as Ferrarelle, Nestlé Waters and San Benedetto. In the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, net revenue generated in the water and beverages end-market represented 10.6% of our net revenue for the period. _Olive oil and condiments_ We offer the oil sector a varied range of long and short capsules, spouts specifically designed for the viscosity of oil, and non-drip devices to prevent dripping at the end of the pour. In the oil and condiments end-market, we primarily sell roll-on aluminum closures to producers of olive oil, such as Carapelli, Deoleo, Unilever and Farchioni group, and vinegar, such as the Ponti group. In the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, net revenue generated in the olive oil and condiments end-market represented 2.5% of our net revenue for the period. _Other markets_ We also sell our products to customers in a broad range of other end-markets, including the pharmaceutical market for PET products. In the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, net revenue generated in other end-market represented 5.1% of our net revenue for the period. We have had relationships with many of our customers for over 30 years. Our top five closures customers the twelve months ended March 31, 2021 were (in alphabetical order) Bacardi, Casa Cuervo, Diageo-USL, Pernod Ricard and Vinventions Deutschland. Together, they represented approximately 30.4% of our net revenue in the twelve months ended March 31, 2021. Certain of our customers own multiple brands. However, no single brand represented more than 3% of our 2020 net revenue as we provide products to multiple brands of several global manufacturers. Our customers spread across a wide range of geographies. Subsubsection Text: Purchasing decisions by our major clients are rarely centralized and are usually made by managers responsible for a single product or brand. With our major customers we enter into a general framework agreement which governs dealings between the parties. Such arrangements generally specify the closure models required, volumes and procedures for determining the purchase price during the term of the contract. Usually a schedule of expected delivery quantities and dates is supplied at regular intervals which enables us to co-ordinate our procurement of raw materials. In order to confirm a particular delivery date and quantity, the customer sends us a purchase order containing the relevant information.

Subsubsection Text: We are active in the design and production of safety, luxury and roll-on closures for spirits, wine, water and beverages, olive oil and other products on a worldwide basis. The broad selection of our closures and our significant diversification means that we face competition from different global and local competitors, which we believe are made up as follows: - non-specialized main competitors, who produce spirits and wine closures on a global scale, without particular specialization in any product; - specialized main competitors, or medium-sized competitors highly specialized, among others, in spirits or wine closures; - non-specialized competitors, who produce packaging on a global scale, with limited market share for spirits and wine closures; and - small, local manufacturers. Our competitive advantages compared to other peers in the closures market include: - our ability to satisfy our customers’ requests, particularly in the spirits market where customers tend to use one manufacturer per product; - our ability to meet specific requests from the market, especially in the safety and luxury market; and - pricing, in particular in the markets of roll-on closures and wine closures. 145 ----- We believe that, as of December 31, 2019, we held a global market share by volume of the safety closures manufactured for spirits of more than 60%. We estimate that in 2020, our market shares for Safety and Roll-on for wine closures was six and four times greater than that of our nearest competitor, respectively. Subsubsection Text: We believe that continuous product innovation is key to our success. The main focus of our research and development activities is on the development and delivery of products that address the quality requirements and design preferences of our customers, by identifying and implementing technical solutions that are more likely to result in innovative and sustainable products, which in turn we expect will boost demand for our products. We also concentrate on standardizing functional components and on developing processes that reduce our operating costs. We currently operate five research and development centers, consisting of our main center, located in in Spinetta Marengo (Alessandria), Italy, as well as four additional centers located in Luxembourg (Foetz), Mexico (San José Iturbide), Ukraine (Sumy) and the United Kingdom (Kirkintilloch). These centres work in collaboration with all of our department and plants. Our research and development center in Italy comprises workshops and dedicated laboratories, collaborates on a regular basis with specialized external research centers, such as universities and private laboratories, and coordinates the operations of our other research centers in Scotland, Mexico, Ukraine and Luxembourg. Our research and development structure consists of engineers, product and mold designers, and product and project managers. As of December 31, 2020, our research and development centers employed a staff of 51 people. Our research and development team continuously seeks to identify new market trends and translate them into smart, sustainable and valuable solutions. Our traditional market is undergoing a period of profound change with customers looking for cost reductions and pushing some brands to the premium level while looking for higher value packaging. Demand for customized, highly technological and sustainable solutions is increasing from both large and established luxury brands and smaller producers, who typically have tighter budgets. In addition, new generations are shifting consumption of alcoholic beverages to craft products, which need to convey their origin in package messaging, as well as wellness and ethical products. Among our most recent innovations, we offer a wide range of e-closures that enable consumers to confirm the authenticity of products and receive other product information through direct engagement with sellers of products. In particular, we developed e-closures with fully integrated NFC capacity, allowing the end customer to connect with the relevant brand and track and trace their products in connection with combatting possible counterfeiting and product tampering. In the spring of 2017, in partnership with NXP Semiconductors, we presented the industry’s first fully integrated NFC tamper-evident closure solution for the wine and spirits industry, part of our new “Internet-of-Closures” smart family products. In addition, starting from 2018, we developed a new series of e-closures with NFC capabilities under the brand NeˇSTGATE[™]. This technology has revolutionized conventional bottle packaging by integrating connectivity features into bottle closures for spirits, wine, olive oil and beverages. In particular, these e-closures are equipped with a special microchip inside the capsule that is readable by all compatible smartphones, without downloading any specific application, providing consumers with the certification of authenticity and unlocking all information about the product, directly linking them to the brand, thus 146 ----- boosting loyalty. Our NeˇSTGATE[™] e-closures include the first wine bottles with e-closures equipped with NFC technology in Europe, which we launched in 2020 together with Vigneti Massa, a well-established winemaker located in the Tortonesi Hills in Piedmont, Italy. We developed this e-closure in collaboration with Compellio, a Luxembourg-based software company. End-customers can take advantage of the technology embedded in these e-closures by creating their own virtual cellar hosted on Compellio’s online platform and receive information on the wine growing areas, the vineyards, the vine, the tasting notes and expert reviews. Customers can also verify the certification of the authenticity of the product using blockchain technology that unequivocally identifies each bottle. Our NeˇSTGATE[™] closures are connected to a blockchain platform which provides a unique identification code for each bottle. This allows Vigneti Massa to protect sensitive product data and monitor them in real time, providing effective support for the traceability of bottles along the supply chain. In 2020, we also launched new NeˇSTGATE[™] e-closures for Irish whiskey Jameson. Our NeˇSTGATE[™] product range also comprises various QR code-based as well as more basic serial number-based models for wine and beverages. Most recently, we designed an electronic tamper-evident closure equipped with proximity sensors capable of detecting nearby objects in partnership with NXP Semiconductors, which we plan to launch in the coming months. In order to refresh our current product portfolio and meet the increasing demand for customized products, our research and development team is currently developing a new series of products tailored for individual brands and equipped with innovative technological and sustainable solutions and with a sophisticated design, which we expect to launch between 2021 and 2023. The laboratory analysis and design of a new model usually takes between four and seven months. The time required for industrialization and production is on average between six and 18 months, depending to a large extent on the technical complexity of the particular product. During the last three years, we have launched over 35 new products. In the year ended December 31, 2020, the costs for research and development activities amounted to €3.1 million, of which €0.7 million was capitalized during the year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Environmental, Social and Governance and Sustainability
Subsubsection Text: We strive to safeguard the environment by reducing the impact of our operations and wider value chain. To achieve such result, we adopted a rigorous environmental policy across all of our facilities focused primarily on (i) research, development and improvement of our products and production processes based on products’ life cycles; (ii) engagement of all our stakeholders, particularly across our supply chain, to meet sustainability objectives; and (iii) implementation of specific and measurable actions for the protection of the environment. Based on our environmental policy, we developed a comprehensive strategy to optimize sustainability across our operations and we identified a series of sustainability targets that we intend to achieve. Among our key objectives, we intend to reduce our Scope 1 and 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions per ton of finished product from our baseline in 2016 by optimizing processes and investing in new equipment for plants as well as optimizing loads and logistics across our supply chain. In addition, we intend to further reduce our energy consumption per ton of finished products. Other key sustainability targets include the reduction of 147 ----- total waste per ton of finished products and of hazardous waste and waste sent to landfill, the reduction of water withdrawal per ton of finished products by 28%, which we have already achieved in 2020, and obtain of the ISO 14001 certification on environmental management for all our facilities. We also intend to increase the overall share of all recycled materials (including both aluminum and plastics) used in our packaging products, which was 27% in 2020. As part of our sustainability plan to increase the use of energy from renewable sources, we launched dedicated programs at some of our plants. In 2020, our plants in Auckland, Sao Paulo, Magenta, Termoli and Olerdola transitioned (fully or at least in part) to electricity produced from renewable sources. In particular, our facility in New Zealand received a full year’s supply of electrical energy from renewable sources in 2020. The Spanish facility in Olerdola began receiving electricity supply entirely from renewable sources in January 2020. In addition, since 2018, the Brazilian facility in São Paulo has received an annual supply of energy from renewable sources covering 100% of consumption. In 2020, we also signed an agreement with an Italian energy supplier to cover the entire electricity consumption of our Magenta and Termoli plants with the supply of electrical energy from renewable sources. In order to make our production process more efficient, improve quality of our products, reduce waste and increase energy and water savings, in the three months ended March 31, 2021, we implemented Iris, a new software developed entirely in-house, at our Spinetta Marengo facility in Italy. This software, which is able to connect 150 machines simultaneously, performs data analysis and makes recommendations to the facility’s operator on how to improve product quality, reduce waste and increase energy and water savings in line with our key sustainability principles. Going forward, we plan to implement the new software at our Termoli and Magenta facilities in Italy, as well as at all of our other facilities worldwide. The efficiency of production processes is key to achieving customer and investor satisfaction and we intend to increase our Overall Equipment Effectiveness (“OEE”), the indicator that measures the total efficiency of plants and equipment, which is calculated as the ratio of output and saturated input, and highlights inefficiencies related to organization, maintenance, production and quality. Our OEE was 76.3% in 2020. We also aim to reduce our average production scrap rate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Environmental, Social and Governance and Sustainability
Subsubsection Text: The commitment to sustainability is an integral part to our corporate culture and lies at the core of our relationship with our employees, customers, suppliers and the broader society in which we operate. We strive to ensure a safe, fair and inclusive working environment for our employees across all of our facilities worldwide. With plants and offices in 25 countries and customers from over 100 countries, we place great importance on diversity and inclusion as well as talent recruitment and management. In 2020, we adopted a dedicated charter of diversity and inclusion, which we applied to all our plants, to ensure equal opportunities and treatment, strengthen our multiculturalism and inclusiveness and to maintain and bolster a sense of belonging. The percentage of women holding leadership positions (i.e., managers) increased from 15.8% as of December 31, 2018 to 20.0% as of March 31, 2021. Following the appointment of the new board of directors on April 30, 2021, 44% of the members of our board of directors are women. We endeavor to safeguard the health and safety of our employees through our “zero accident” strategy, which aims at reducing the frequency rates of work-related injuries. Our accident frequency rate (number of incidents per million hours worked) has been decreasing consistently over time and in 2020, we recorded 63 incidents, compared to 88 in 2019, with a decrease in the frequency rate of 22.8%, from 7.71 to 5.95. The rate of accident severity (days of absence per incident per thousand hours worked) also decreased by approximately 40% from 0.30 to 0.18 from 2019 to 2020. Overall, we place a great importance on our corporate social responsibility and our public image and endeavor to apply the highest ethical and legal standards when shaping our strategic goals and in our daily business activities. We strive to incorporate ethical and social responsibility principles in our internal guidelines and procedures. In addition, we give our employees extensive opportunities to develop their skills and talents and offer various training courses on their work and job security and we promote the environmental awareness of the people who work for us through training courses. In addition, we work to support the countries in which we operate and seek to give back to local communities through impactful community projects to support the developing countries in which we operate (including India, Colombia and Mexico), including through various reforestation projects to offset our Scope 1 Greenhouse Gas Emissions which we started in 2011. We also offset carbon dioxide through reforestation projects in collaboration with international NGOs and the purchase of carbon credits (i.e., 148 ----- certificates equivalent to one ton of CO2 per certificate, not emitted or absorbed as the result of an environmental protection project aimed at reducing or reabsorbing global emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases). We developed these projects with influential partners and independent international certified agencies that audited our activities. By the end of 2020, we have planted over 390,000 trees and involved more than 6,500 people in the various projects across the developing countries in which we operate. Examples of other projects to support local communities in the countries in which we operate, include the distribution of “dignity kits”, which include sanitary towels, undergarments and training on menstrual education to teenage girls across Kenya, and the development and sponsorship of environmental education to thousands of students in India.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Environmental, Social and Governance and Sustainability
Subsubsection Text: Sustainability and zero-environmental impact packages are becoming increasingly important. Our products and customers are the top priorities of our ESG and sustainability strategy, and this is reflected in our focus on product innovation and design. In order to provide a range of harmonized sustainable packaging solutions, we have developed specific guidelines for eco-design which we have adopted at our five research and development centers in September 2020. Our eco-design guidelines are based on four defined design templates: (i) design to _reduce, based on reducing raw materials used in the manufacturing of our products, which decreases the_ overall impact of our operations on the environment; (ii) design to change, based on increasing the use of recycled materials in our products, including aluminum and certain types of polymers as well as wood; (iii) design to fade, focused on eliminating waste by using biodegradable polymers; and (iv) design to revive, based on recycling our end-products to reduce scrap pollution and waste. In line with our long-term commitment to design sustainable solutions, in November 2020, we launched a new range of sustainable products under the umbrella brand Blossom[™], which includes products such as Greencap[®], a fully removable and disposable aluminum screwcap made of recycled materials, a luxury T-bar closure fully made of recycled ocean-diverted plastic and agglomerated cork that we developed in collaboration with Oceanworks[®], the largest global marketplace for sustainable materials, and Spring Blossom, a new aluminum closure for water with a tamper-evident ring produced from completely bio-based polymers. Our research and development team focuses on the studying and prototyping closures made of materials and technical solutions that reduce the environmental impact of packaging over its life cycle, including recycled polymers, biopolymers and composite polymers. To achieve such result, we study and analyze the various phases of a product’s life, from the production of selected raw materials to end-of-life treatment, by using tools developed by us together with selected partners. In 2020, we signed contracts with new suppliers of recycled polymers and carried out plastic moulding tests, especially for the production of PET bottles, one of the few plastic materials that has a specific recycling chain. In December 2020, we signed an exclusivity agreement with Oceanworks[®], the largest global marketplace for sustainable materials, in order to develop a line of T-bar closures manufactured using fully recycled ocean-diverted plastic. Customer satisfaction is a key element of our corporate culture and we strive to provide punctual, effective and high quality customer service. We measure our customer service level by monitoring the “On Time and In Full” or “OTIF” indicator, which considers the percentage of deliveries made on time and in full compared to the total number of shipments made. In 2020, our OTIF reached 89.8% despite the COVID-19 pandemic. We leverage our network of plants to ensure continuity of service to customers, reducing the risk of service disruptions as well as interruptions in the supply of utilities and malfunctions. We also agreed continuity plans with our major customers that include production in alternative plants or the identification of backup warehouses. In addition, we launched projects to reduce the environmental impact of product packaging across several plants (including in Italy, France, Ukraine and Scotland) in order to both replace cardboard boxes with reusable plastic packaging (in collaboration with some important customers) and replace disposable wooden pallets with reusable recycled plastic pallets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Environmental, Social and Governance and Sustainability
Subsubsection Text: Over the last decade, we have established a strong focus on Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) and sustainability trends in our key end-markets. This is supported by our sustainable manufacturing process focused on protecting the environment, while not compromising the high quality of our products. Our ESG strategy is based on three key pillars, the planet, our people and our business, and comprises a series of key performance indicators and targets that we intend to achieve. To ensure the effective implementation of our sustainability strategy and monitor our ongoing progress, in 2015 we set up our “Green Board”, chaired by our Chief Operating Officer and composed of twelve managers, of which eight corporate department heads and four country managers from different geographical areas and continents. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, 2021, 50% of the members of our Green Board were women. Our sustainability team (which is different from our “Green Board”) is responsible for the implementation and sharing of sustainability reporting at the Group level, the coordination of the activities for the certification of environmental data and the review of the non-financial statement data carried out by third-party companies as well as the implementation of inputs from the Green Board meetings. We also have dedicated sustainability teams in each country and CSR managers at each business unit.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We rely on a combination of patents, utility models, trade secrets, trademarks, copyrights and other intellectual property rights, non-disclosure agreements and other protective measures to protect our 149 ----- proprietary rights. We strongly believe in the importance of intellectual property rights, which in our view is one of the key elements of our current business. We employ various methods, including confidentiality and non-disclosure agreements with third parties, employees and consultants to protect our trade secrets and know-how. As of March 31, 2021, we held, or had lodged applications for, more than 170 patents, including 113 active patent families, 10 utility model families, 5 combined patents and utility model families and 44 protected industrial designs. The patents and other IP have been registered predominantly in countries in which our production facilities are located, or in countries in which our major customers are based. We have been active in the production of safety closures since the 1970s when we launched the famous 1031 model safety closure. Most of our older patents related to the creation of innovative solutions for tamper-evident and tamper proofing features in closures with these features being implemented alongside new designs of plastic components and the interaction of plastic components with aluminum shells. Our more recent patent applications take advantage of new technologies in an innovative manner and for the first time in the closures field, include production cost savings and sustainable methods (for waste reduction) as well as improvements in the efficiency of tamper-evident and anti-counterfeiting measures.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We reach our customer base primarily through our direct sales force. Our sales force is organized geographically and is able to focus on target markets and customers by understanding local needs. In certain markets, we enter into agency agreements with independent sales agents or use distributors in order to benefit from established local sales channels or because market conditions demand their use. We tailor our marketing activities primarily on the basis of our current level of penetration in a specific market. Our marketing strategy involves publication of advertisements in sector paid media (online and paper-based), participation in specialized conferences and use of digital marketing tools, public relations and communication agencies and ad hoc sponsorships. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have intensified our marketing activities via webinars and virtual conferences and we expect this trend to continue in the future. Participation at annual trade fairs for packaging, spirits, wine and water and beverage industries is another important means of keeping in contact with customers, particularly in the earlier stages of our entrance into a market when we have lower brand awareness and limited access to the market, for example, when we originally entered South East Asia (in Japan and Bangkok), Africa (in Nigeria and Kenya), and the United States.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We purchase aluminum in coil and aluminum foil from a number of suppliers which we select based on technical criteria, service quality, reliability and sustainability parameters. Our principal suppliers of aluminum are located in Europe and most of the aluminum we used is produced by the Magenta facility and then allocated to our facilities worldwide. However, our plants in Poland, Ukraine, South Africa, Argentina and Australia purchase part of the aluminum they use from third-party suppliers. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we used a total of 35,481 tons of aluminum. Our aluminum purchase agreements specify quality and performance levels, technical specifications of the product, price breakdowns, total processing costs, delivery plans and payment schedules and minimum purchase quantities for annual consumption. We also purchase aluminum ingots on the spot market, which we then dispatch for processing to suppliers of aluminum coil. In addition, we meet part of our demand of aluminum through a transformation process of aluminum stemming from production waste. In addition, we use more than 43,000 tons per year of different types of plastics. The majority of our purchases of plastic resins are made on the basis of purchase orders from a number of leading European and world producers. While we have a central control of plastic purchase price, raw materials are primarily sourced locally. Our key plastic resins suppliers for our European production facilities are located in Italy, France, Germany and Belgium. The majority of the plastics resins used in production are low and highdensity polyethylene, polystyrene, polypropylene and polycarbonate. Our supply requirements contracts with our principal suppliers set out the terms of payment, delivery schedules and the criteria for determining any price and volume discounts (usually conditional upon us meeting specified purchase targets). Our supply contracts also provide for adjustments of prices depending on periodic increases or 150 ----- decreases in plastic resins prices, which, in turn, change on a weekly basis, except in the case of polycarbonate, the price of which is generally set for periods of several months. In the year ended December 31, 2020, the share of recycled raw materials used in our products was 27% compared to 23% in 2018, and we intend to increase it to 35% by the end of 2025. Raw materials prices can fluctuate substantially over relatively short periods of time. Increases in the prices of our raw materials have therefore had a direct impact on our production costs. We are able to manage this by reducing the quantity of aluminum used in our manufacturing process and substituting it with other raw materials. Since most of our closures division sales are made on the basis of contracts that fix our sales prices for the term of each contract (generally one year) or are otherwise made pursuant to purchase orders that do not link sales prices to increases in the cost of raw materials, our closures division margins are exposed to the risk of fluctuations of the prices of raw materials. In order to mitigate our exposure to such risks, we select our suppliers very carefully. We also continually seek to implement innovative product and process solutions aimed at reducing consumption of raw materials. Additionally, in respect of aluminum, we use hedging instruments to reduce our exposure to price fluctuations. We typically purchase aluminum based on contracts that set prices by reference to the aluminum quotations on the London Metal Exchange in euro or U.S. dollars, which are converted into euro at the average exchange rate at the month of purchase. We seek to reduce our exposure to the risks associated with aluminum price fluctuations by entering into forward contracts with brokers operating on the London Metal Exchange, whereby we purchase aluminum at a fixed price to protect our operating margins from price volatility. Our forward hedging transactions covered approximately 60% of our aluminum supplies at December 31, 2020. Our forward hedging transactions currently cover approximately 70% of our estimated 2021 aluminum needs. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Principal factors _affecting our results of operations—Costs for raw materials”. To date we have not entered into similar_ hedging arrangements in respect of plastic price fluctuations, because such arrangements are not currently available in the market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The production process for safety closures and for aluminum shells is divided into three stages: (i) injection molding of plastic components and for aluminum shell production, (ii) customization and (iii) assembly. We first produce each plastic component by using injection molding technology developed by our in-house personnel. Our closures are then customized by applying surface decoration through various techniques, such as off-set, silk screen or tomographic printing, or hot-stamping. Finally, we assemble the plastic safety closure itself and are able to assemble multiple components at high speed. As part of our continuous effort to make our manufacturing process more efficient by leveraging technological innovations, we are implementing a multi-injection project to develop closures made of different plastics in the same mould in order to eliminate the assembly stage of our manufacturing process and provide significant additional anti-counterfeiting protection to our closures. In addition, we focus on wide-scale flexible automation of our productions process, which we plan to implement also for small and medium-sized product batches. The luxury product line uses the same processing techniques as our safety closures product line, but extra attention is paid to aesthetic design. The process may involve “metallization” of the capsule or applying other special finishes, depending on the characteristics of the end-product. The production process of roll-on aluminum closures and screwcaps for wine closures begins with the aluminum coil being washed and cleaned. The sheets are printed and pressed into different shells and aluminum rings. If a customer wishes to have a more aesthetically appealing design or to customize the closure with a particular color or with the company’s trademark, we perform side-printing using off-set and silk-screen techniques. The final stage of the production process is the assembly of the aluminum closure where we insert seals or plastic components such as non-drip spouts or flow inhibitors. Some pharmaceutical closures use rubber which is cut to the correct shape then washed and sterilized. We have warehouses adjacent to almost all the production facilities. Our plastic materials are kept in dedicated silos to avoid jeopardizing the purity of our end-products. Since our finished products are generally shipped directly to customers soon after production, they are stored only for limited periods of time. 151 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2021, most of our closures division production facilities have been ISO 9001:2015 certified, which requires compliance with a set of shipping, trading and technology standards promulgated by the International Organization for Standardization (“ISO”). In addition, as of March 31, 2021, the majority of our production facilities obtained the ISO 22000:2018 certification for food safety management systems and the 14001 certification for environmental management systems. We intend to obtain these certifications for all of our plants by the end of 2022. In order to offer objective guarantees of compliance with occupational, health and safety, environmental and ethics standards, we have joined the SEDEX (social ethical data exchange) platform with the aim of keeping information on all plants updated, making it transparent to customers and having our plants subject to SMETA audits by third parties. As of March 31, 2021, all of our plants were included in the platform, and in 2020 SMETA audits were carried out at four of our plants, the relevant audit reports were made available to our customers and we are implementing any necessary measures in light of their findings and recommendations. All of our facilities utilize efficient quality control and certification processes for raw materials. We perform regular quality controls on the raw materials that are supplied to us by our suppliers. Our technical staff checks the technical characteristics, including the purity and quality of polymers, their resistance to pressure and shock, their conformity with EU regulations governing packaging materials for food, and their resistance to the effects of alcohol. Moreover, plastics are also tested to ensure that they do not affect the taste of spirits. We operate an advanced quality assurance process to improve the quality performance of all our facilities. Qualified staff at each production facility carry out tests on raw materials, processes and end-products to improve quality and adopt corrective or preventive measures to ensure a high level of efficiency throughout our production chain. These processes include the use of statistical process control and we involve our employees in on-going monitoring activities. We believe that this approach to quality control increases employee participation and provides necessary training at all levels. The staff assigned to this task have an active role in the development and modernization of our production facilities. We monitor the quality of our finished products to ensure that our products fully meet our customers’ requirements and expectations. We believe that our quality assurance practices are critical to improving our internal processes and the service we provide to our customers. In addition to our internal quality control operations, we offer our customers the opportunity to send their personnel to our closures division facilities periodically to verify the quality of our products and the production process. Those of our facilities that manufacture products for the mineral water market also meet stringent requirements regarding facility hygiene.

Pursuant to applicable Italian law, the Issuer has appointed a board of statutory auditors (Collegio _Sindacale) whose objective is to oversee the Issuer’s compliance with the law and with its by-laws, verify its_ compliance to best practices of administration, and assess the adequacy of the internal controls and accounting reporting systems at the Issuer, as well as the adequacy of provisions concerning the supply of information to its subsidiaries. The Board of Statutory Auditors is formed by three auditors and two alternative auditors. 157 ----- Members of the board of statutory auditors are appointed by the shareholders of the Issuer at ordinary shareholders’ meetings for a three-year term expiring on the date of the ordinary shareholders’ meeting called to approve the financial statements for the third financial year of their term. Members of the board of statutory are appointed on the basis of lists submitted by shareholders. At least one of the auditors and one of the alternate auditors must be selected among legal auditors registered with the relevant special registry. Members of the board of statutory auditors may be removed only for a valid reason and with the approval of an Italian court. Following completion of Sell-Out and Squeeze-Out procedures, Guala’s ordinary shares and Market Warrants will be delisted from the Mercato Telematico Azionario organized and managed by Borsa Italiana S.p.A. and Guala will cease to be a publicly listed Company. Subsubsection Text: The Remuneration and Nomination Committee was formed on April 30, 2021 and, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Chiara Palmieri (President), Marina Brogi (independent director) and Dante Razzano (director) are the members of the Remuneration Committee. 158 ----- The Remuneration and Nomination Committee pays an advisory and consulting role in the remuneration and appointment of directors and key executives. The creation of the Remuneration and Nomination Committee facilitates maximum information and transparency regarding the compensation due to the CEO and other top management. However, pursuant to article 2389(3) of the Italian Civil Code and article 15 of the Issuer’s By-Laws, the Remuneration and Nomination Committee only offers advice and recommendation, as the power to determine compensation remains with the Board of Directors, with advice from the Board of the Statutory Auditors.

Subsubsection Text: Parties Policy, expresses opinions on certain transactions deemed to be between related parties, participates in the negotiation of related party transactions deemed to be of greater importance and provides assistance in connection with the identification of related parties. The new sustainability role of this committee was identified in accordance with the Shareholder Rights Directive II of the European Union, which is aimed, among other things, at strengthening the role of finance in the transition to a sustainable economy, managing financial risks associated with ESG aspects more effectively and encouraging a long-term investment approach. The specific functions and duties of the Control, Risks and Sustainability Committee with regard to sustainability will be defined by the Board of Directors.

Subsection Title: Compliance Program Supervisory Board ex D. Lgs. 231/2001
Subsubsection Text: On April 30, 2020, the Board of Directors appointed Roberta Barristin (President) and Ascensionato Carnà as members of the Compliance Program Supervisory Board, adopted pursuant to Legislative Decree 231/2001. The Compliance Program Supervisory Board supervises the implementation of and compliance with the organizational and management model adopted in compliance with Legislative Decree 231/2001. The model sets forth a series of principles, policies, procedures and control functions to prevent the commission of relevant offenses by individuals acting on behalf of the Issuer, as well as the corresponding penalties. 159 -----

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer has outstanding share capital of €68,906,646. As of March 31, 2021, the Issuer had 67,184,904 outstanding shares without nominal value, which were split into 62,049,966 ordinary shares, 4,322,438 Class B special shares and 812,500 Class C special shares. The ordinary shares entitle the holders to one vote per share, Class B special shares entitle the holders to three votes per share and Class C special shares are non-voting. The ordinary shares are the only shares of the Issuer that are listed on the Star segment of the Italian Stock Exchange (Mercato _Telematico Azioniario)._ In accordance with the Issuer’s by-laws, on March 29, 2021, the 812,500 Class C special shares were converted into 3,656,250 ordinary shares, using a ratio of 1 Class C share to 4.5 ordinary shares. On April 6, 2021, the Class C shares were cancelled and on April 7, 2021, the 3,656,250 ordinary shares were issued. On May 31, 2021, upon request of GCL Holdings S.à r.l. and in accordance with the provisions of the Issuer’s by-laws, all of the 4,322,438 Class B special shares were converted into ordinary shares at a conversion ratio of 1 Class B share to 1 ordinary share. As a result, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer’s share capital is composed of 70,028,654 ordinary shares without nominal value, zero (0) Class B special shares and zero (0) Class C special shares. On June 14, 2021, SPSI completed the Offers for the outstanding share capital and Market Warrants of the Issuer. As a result of the Offers, on June 18, 2021, SPSI commenced the Sell-Out procedure, which will be completed on July 8, 2021. If, as a result of the Sell-Out, SPSI comes to own at least 95% of the share capital of Guala, SPSI will commence the Squeeze-Out procedure, as a result of which SPSI will become the sole shareholder of the Issuer. In addition to the ordinary shares, the Issuer issued three different kinds of warrants: (i) the Market Warrants, that as of the date of this Offering Memorandum are listed on the Italian Stock Exchange (Mercato Telematico Azioniario); (ii) the “sponsor warrants” held by Space Holding S.r.l. as promoter of Space4; and (iii) the “management warrants”. Each of the different types of warrants issued by the Issuer grants the right to the respective holders to subscribe to a predetermined number of the Issuer’s ordinary shares upon occurrence of certain events and in accordance with the respective regulations providing terms and conditions of the warrants. In particular, pursuant to the respective regulations: (i) the Market Warrants become exercisable when the ordinary shares reach a monthly average price recorded on the Italian Stock Exchange (Mercato Telematico Azioniario) of more than €10.00 per ordinary share, while (ii) the sponsor warrants and the management warrants become exercisable when the ordinary shares reach an official price (recorded on at least one trading day on the Italian Stock Exchange (Mercato _Telematico Azioniario)) equal to or greater than €13.00 per share. The regulations of the warrants will be_ amended upon occurrence of certain events (including upon merger of the Issuer into a non-listed 160 ----- company). Upon completion of the Sell-Out and the Delisting, the Market Warrants will remain outstanding but will no longer be exercisable by their respective holders, except in case of re-listing of the Issuer’s ordinary shares on the Italian Stock Exchange (Mercato Telematico Azioniario). Following completion of the Voluntary Offer, as of June 18, 2021, SPSI held 16.809.156 Market Warrants, representing 86.8% of all outstanding Market Warrants. We will reassess the fair value of the Market Warrants and the related liabilities following the Offers in connection with the preparation of our financial statements for the second quarter of 2021. In connection with the Transactions, prior to the Issue Date, the Issuer shall enter into a super senior revolving credit facility agreement with, among others, U.S. Bank Global Corporate Trust Limited, as the agent, and U.S. Bank Trustees Limited, as the security agent (the “Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”). The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides for a super senior revolving credit facility in a principal amount of €80.0 million. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which accede to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as additional borrowers of that facility (the “SSRCF Borrowers”) and may be applied in or towards (directly or indirectly) (x) financing or refinancing the working capital requirements and/or the general corporate purposes of the Group and (x) any other purpose contemplated by the funds flow statement or the tax structure memorandum in connection with the Transactions. The Revolving Credit Facility will be available in euros, sterling and U.S. dollars and certain other currencies readily available in the relevant interbank market by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities (on a bilateral and fronted basis).

The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the date of the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, provided that the Notes have been issued, to (and including) the date which is one (1) month prior to the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility.
Utilizations of the Revolving Credit Facility are subject to customary conditions precedent.

Loans under the Revolving Credit Facility will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR for loans denominated in euro, a rate based on, SONIA for loans denominated in sterling, or for loans denominated other than in euro or sterling, LIBOR, plus an applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Debt as at the last day of the relevant period to Consolidated Pro Forma EBITDA in respect of that relevant period (each as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) (the “Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio”). In addition, the margin for the Revolving Credit Facility may reduce further whilst a Suspension Event is continuing. If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility. If LIBOR is less than zero, LIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility. If SONIA is less than zero, SONIA shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility. A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility from the Closing Date (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the “Closing Date”) to the end of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of thirty (30)% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which the relevant lender cancels its commitment. Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

The loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings. All outstanding amounts under the 163 ----- Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the date falling seventy eight (78) months from the Issue Date. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain conditions. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement allows for voluntary prepayments (subject to de minimis amounts). The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also permits each lender to require the mandatory prepayment of all amounts due to that lender upon a “Change of Control” within time periods set out in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. A “Change of Control” for the purposes of the Revolving Credit Facility is defined as per the Notes, save that, in addition, on and from the date that SPSI is the 100% shareholder of the Issuer, it shall also constitute a “Change of Control” under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement if persons providing third party security for the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement cease to directly own 100% of shares in the Issuer.

The Revolving Credit Facility will be initially guaranteed by the Issuer. The Revolving Credit Facility will be secured by the Collateral that also secures the Notes as set forth under “Description of the Notes—Security.” The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides that material subsidiaries (wholly owned members of the Group whose earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization (calculated on the same bases as Consolidated EBITDA) represent more than five (5) per cent. of Consolidated EBITDA) (the “Material Subsidiaries”) which are not incorporated in certain excluded jurisdictions will subject to the terms of the Agreed Security Principles set out therein (the “Agreed Security Principles”) guarantee the Facilities and, provide security over (x) shares owned by such Material Subsidiaries in other Material Subsidiaries and (y) material, structural, long term, documented recievables owed to such person by any other Material Subsidiary not incorporated in an excluded jurisdiction. Subject to certain adjustments and the Agreed Security Principles, the Issuer is required to ensure that members of the Group that (x) are Material Subsidiaries which are not incorporated in certain excluded jurisdictions and/or (y) collectively contribute in aggregate at least eighty (80) per cent. of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and subject to certain adjustments as set out therein) are guarantors of the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (i) 180 days after the Closing Date and (ii) thereafter within 180 days of the latest due date when the annual financial statements of the Issuer are required to be delivered to the agent in connection with the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. The provision and the terms of the security and guarantees set forth above will in all cases be subject to certain limitations and are at all times and in all cases subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the requirements of applicable law and the other matters set forth in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (and, to the extent such requirement is not satisfied on such date, the Issuer shall ensure that it is so satisfied within 180 days of such date).

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain representations and warranties (subject to certain agreed qualifications and with certain representations being repeated), including, among others, (i) status, binding obligations, non-conflict with other obligations, power and authority, governing law and enforcement, validity and admissibility in evidence and pari passu ranking, (ii) no insolvency, taxation and no litigation, (iii) no default, financial statements, (iv) good title to assets,, and (v) centre of main interests and compliance with sanctions and anti-corruption laws. Certain representations and warranties will be made on the Closing Date and will be repeated on the date of each utilization, on the first day of each interest period (other than in the case of roll over cash drawings) and at certain other times.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain of the incurrence covenants and related definitions (with certain adjustments and exceptions) that are set forth in the Indenture. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also requires the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries to observe certain other customary positive and negative covenants, subject to certain 164 ----- exceptions and grace periods, including covenants relating to (i) authorizations, (ii) compliance with laws; (iii) centre of main interests; (iv) provision of guarantees and security (v) compliance with sanctions, antimoney laundering and anti- corruption laws, (vi) further assurance and (vii) conditions subsequent.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides for substantially the same events of default as under the Notes. In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to customary materiality qualifications and grace periods, including (i) inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made, (ii) unlawfulness and invalidity of the Revolving Credit Facility financing documents (including the applicable security documents), (iii) material failure to comply with the Intercreditor Agreement and (iv) repudiation or rescission of the Revolving Credit Facility financing documents (including the applicable security documents).

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it, are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in accordance with English law although the information undertakings, restrictive covenants, events of default and related definitions scheduled to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will be interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact that the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement is governed by English law).

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, on or prior to the Issue Date, the Issuer shall into an Intercreditor Agreement between, among others, the agent, arrangers and lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Trustee and the Security Agent. By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Issuer and any other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Third Party Security Provider, when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or Third Party Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and provisions related to the enforcement of shared security. The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and not the discussion that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes and of the Trustee. Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement. References to “agent or trustee” shall also be references to such person as “mandatario con rappresentanza”. For the purposes of this description: “Senior Secured Group” shall mean the Issuer and any of its Restricted Subsidiaries. References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include the Notes and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by a member of the Senior Secured Group which are designated by the Issuer as Senior Secured Notes under the Intercreditor Agreement.

_Priority of Debts_ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by the Issuer and each other debtor under the Intercreditor Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than any person which is designated as a Topco Borrower under the Intercreditor Agreement (a “Topco Borrower”)) shall rank in right and 165 ----- priority of payment in the following order and are postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows: (i) first, liabilities owed to (i) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to any senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement”) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities”), (ii) the lenders, issuing banks, and ancillary lenders in relation to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement or any future super senior facilities agreement (a “Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement”) and any hedge counterparty under a hedging agreement that is designated by the Issuer as super senior (together the “Super Senior Liabilities” and creditors thereof being the “Super Senior Creditors”), (iii) the Trustee and any trustee in relation to the Notes and any future senior secured notes (each a “Senior Secured Notes Trustee”) (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the holders of the Notes or future senior secured notes (the “Senior Secured Notes”) and the Security Agent in relation to the Senior Secured Notes (the “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities”), (iv) the lender under any future loan made by the issuer of any Senior Secured Notes (if so designated by the Issuer in its discretion and not including, for the avoidance of doubt, the Issuer) to a member of the Senior Secured Group for the purposes of on lending the proceeds of any Senior Secured Notes together with any additional or replacement loan made on substantially the same terms (the “Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), (v) the arrangers, agents, issuing banks and lenders under any cash management facility (a “Cash Management Facility” and the liabilities under a Cash Management Facility being the “Cash Management Facility Liabilities”), (vi) the hedge counterparties in relation to any hedging agreements that are not Super Senior Liabilities (the “Pari Passu Hedging Liabilities”) (together with the hedging designated by the Issuer as being Super Senior Liabilities, the “Hedging Liabilities”), (vii) the lenders in relation to any future second lien facility agreement (a “Second Lien Facility Agreement” and the liabilities to the lenders under a Second Lien Facility Agreement being the “Second Lien Lender Liabilities”), (viii) any second lien notes trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the holders of any future second lien notes and the Security Agent in relation to any second lien notes (such second lien notes being “Second Lien Notes” and the liabilities in respect of such Second Lien Notes being the “Second Lien Notes Liabilities” and together with the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, the “Second Lien Liabilities”), (ix) any agent or trustee under any finance documents relating to any of the aforementioned liabilities, any agent or trustee under the Topco Liabilities (as defined below) and to any agent or trustee in relation to certain other unsecured liabilities (together the “Agent Liabilities”), (x) any arranger under any finance documents (the “Arranger Liabilities”) relating to any of the aforementioned liabilities, and (xi) the Security Agent, pari passu and without any preference between them; and (ii) second, all liabilities owed (i) to the trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as Trustee), and the holders of any future notes issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) has been made available to or by a Topco Borrower and designated by the Issuer as Topco Notes and the Security Agent in relation to such Topco Notes (the “Topco Notes Liabilities”), (ii) under any future loan facility made available to any Topco Borrower (the “Topco Facility Liabilities” and together with the Topco Notes Liabilities, the “Topco Liabilities”), (iii) any Arranger Liabilities relating to any of the aforementioned liabilities, and (iv) the liabilities owed under any future loan (a “Topco Proceeds Loan”) made by any Topco Borrower for the purpose of on lending the proceeds of any Topco Notes or Topco Loans (the “Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), pari passu and without any preference between them. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by any Topco Borrower to the Secured Parties (as defined below) shall rank pari passu in right and priority of payment and without any preference between them in respect of (i) the Senior Lender Liabilities, (ii) the Super Senior Liabilities, (iii) the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, (iv) the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, (v) the Hedging Liabilities, (vi) the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, (vii) the Second Lien Notes Liabilities, (viii) the Topco Liabilities, (ix) the Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities and (x) the Agent Liabilities and Arranger Liabilities in respect of any of the aforementioned liabilities. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the intra-group liabilities owed by one member of the Senior Secured Group to another member of the Senior Secured Group (other than any Subordinated Liabilities (as defined below), Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities or Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities) (the “Intra- Group Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the liabilities owed by the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the creditors under the Senior Lender Liabilities, Super Senior 166 ----- Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Cash Management Facility Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities, Second Lien Lender Liabilities, Second Lien Notes Liabilities, Topco Liabilities and Agent Liabilities and Arranger Liabilities relating to any of the aforementioned (such creditors, together with the Security Agent, any receiver or delegate, any creditor in respect of the Agent Liabilities or the Arranger Liabilities, the “Secured Parties”). The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the liabilities owed by any member of the Senior Secured Group to any person who becomes a subordinated creditor (a “Subordinated Creditor”) under the Intercreditor Agreement (other than any Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities or any Topco Liabilities or any amounts owed to an affiliate of a Subordinated Creditor which is not itself a Subordinated Creditor or a member of the Topco Group (as defined below)) (the “Subordinated Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the liabilities owed by the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties, the unsecured liabilities of any unsecured creditors who are party to the Intercreditor Agreement (the “Unsecured Creditors”) and to the Intra-Group Liabilities. _Priority of The Intercreditor Agreement provides, subject to certain conditions, for the implementation of existing, additional, supplemental or new financing arrangements that will constitute, for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement, Senior Lender Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Cash Management Facility Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities, Topco Liabilities, Super Senior Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities or Unsecured Liabilities (each a “New Debt Financing”). The conditions include certification by the Issuer that such New Debt Financing is not prohibited under the terms of the Finance Documents. Such financing arrangements may be implemented by way of refinancing, replacement, exchange, set-off, discharge or increase of any such new, existing, additional, supplemental or new financing arrangement under the relevant finance documents. In connection with and in order to facilitate any New Debt Financing, each agent in respect of any Secured Liabilities and the Security Agent (and each other person party to a Transaction Security document or a Topco Independent Transaction Security Document) is authorized and instructed to enter promptly into any new security document, promptly 169 ----- amend or waive any term of an existing security document and/or promptly release any asset from the Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be) and/or to effect the ranking, priority guarantees and security of the New Debt Financing subject to certain conditions, including as regards the terms of such new security (which shall be, unless otherwise required by the Issuer), substantially the same as the terms of the existing Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security). Any release and re-grant of Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security may only be undertaken if (i) (A) required under the New Debt Financing; (B) necessary under applicable law to give effect to the ranking as described under “—Priority of Security” above; or (C) the Issuer has determined in good faith that it is either not possible or not desirable to implement the New Debt Financing on terms satisfactory to the Issuer by instead granting additional Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be) and/or amending the terms of the existing Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be); and (ii) if any asset is to be released from Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be), promptly upon giving effect to that release, replacement Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be) is, subject to certain conditions, granted in favor of the Security Agent for and on behalf of the providers and/or agents and/or trustees of the New Debt Financing and (in relation to the Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be)) the existing Secured Parties (or relevant class thereof) or Topco Creditors (as the case may be) benefitting from the Security on substantially the same terms as the Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be) released (except that it shall also secure any New Debt Financing). Each Secured Party agrees (i) not to take any action to challenge the validity or enforceability of additional Transaction Security or Topco Independent Transaction Security (as the case may be) by reason of it being expressed to be second ranking; (ii) that additional Transaction Security may be granted by any Debtor to secure all or any part of any Hedging Liabilities and/or New Debt Financing and (iii) the Additional Topco Independent Transaction Security may be granted by any Topco Independent Obligor to secure all or any part of any New Debt Financing. Any security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance against loss in respect of a New Debt Financing or in respect of any indebtedness (“Permitted Acquired Indebtedness”) which is not prohibited by the terms of the Finance Documents and which is incurred by or in connection with the acquisition of (i) a person or any of its subsidiaries who becomes a Restricted Subsidiary after the Closing Date or (ii) a person that merges, consolidates or is otherwise combined with a Restricted Subsidiary after the Closing Date, or (iii) the assets of or shares in any person listed in paragraphs (i) or (ii) above or otherwise acquired after the Closing Date (together an “Acquired Person or Asset”), shall be permitted to subsist (or to be granted in accordance with the applicable terms) and there is no requirement to offer that security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance in respect of any other liabilities under any Debt Document. No security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance against loss is required to be given by any member of the Topco Group in respect of any liabilities (including under any Debt Document) (i) over any Acquired Person or Asset if this would breach a contractual undertaking applicable to the Topco Group or is excluded or exempt from being given under the Agreed Security Principles, (ii) over any asset required (including subject to any condition) to provide credit support in relation to any Permitted Acquired Indebtedness (other than as a result of any obligation to extend any Transaction Security ratably for the benefit of such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness), or (iii) where the grant of such security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance against loss is prevented by the documentation in relation to such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness or would give rise to an obligation (including any payment obligation but not including an obligation to extend any Transaction Security ratably for the benefit of such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness) under or in relation thereto.
